content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												Simple 4x game, nice introduction to the genre or a nice casual experience for the pro.It's not got the complexity of other 4x games, instead Warlock goes down the route of funziez. It's a very casual experience that after a while can lose it's charm and turn into mediocrirt but for the first 10-20 hours will hold your attention competently.Don't bother putting it on the highest difficulty, the ai spams an ocean of units and it's just ridiculous. There are many types of units with various abilites but nothing really new.I like how your spells can interact with the landscape to create mountains and oceans. Levelling up was fun but a clear rip off of civ 5.eventually the game feels stale, lifeless and mundane. It's probably you won''t finish a campaign before your too bored to go on.not a very good 4x but fun for a good while. Worth it for £5 even if you've played all the other 4x games or are not up for learning anythign complex.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2012
												As long as you think of Warlock as "Civilization Fantasy Lite", you'll have a lot of fun. Just don't expect a deep tactical strategy game, though. Almost everything about Warlock is extremely simplistic: from spells to combat to enemy AI to diplomacy, there's very little deep thinking in the game. Diplomacy in particular is a bit daft -- there are few options aside from trade and basic alliance requests, and the only choices when facing an opponent's demands for physical goods are "Accept" or "Declare War". Also, as i s the case with virtually every Civ-like strategy game ever made, the AI will start to cheat once you gain an advantage.Overall, Warlock is pretty addictive. There are a ton of different units and abilities, and each race has distinctive perks. But as of now, it's way too easy to steamroll the closest AI opponent early on, thereby allowing you complete domination of your region before even setting sights on the next AI player. Hopefully the devs fix the inconsistencies.

Posted: July 30, 2012
												Con sabor a sagas clásicas como Master of Magic o Age of Wonders, Warlock no deja de ser un juego inspirado de manera más que evidente por otra saga legendaria, Civilization. La gran diferencia está en que aquí el único camino posible para la victoria es la guerra: estarás todo el tiempo ocupado resistiendo ataques por parte de los magos rivales o preparandote para tu próxima campaña militar, siendo la expasión por el mapa una mera excusa para obtener más recursos con los que aumentar tu ejercito. También tendrás la posibilidad de investigar hechizos y lanzarlos en cualquier punto del mapa, como no podía ser de otra manera.Le falta aún pulirse y expandir algo más ciertos puntos de su mecánica de juego, pero en su estado actual es endiabladamente adictivo, como todo buen clon de Civilization.

Posted: February 9, 2015
												THERE IS NO CAMPAIGN! - for those who may be buying to play through some Epic 4x story mode.This game is all skirmish all the time.Pick a pre-gen'd mage or make your own with a selection of portraits, name change,  spells/traits/start bonuses and the choice of commanding 1 of 4 different races (each with their own benefits of course) as your main "civ"5 difficulties to accompany all players and to increase as you become better.4 different map types (based on Water : Land ratio), and 4 map sizes. And the option of cylindrical or flat (so you can either exit one side and appear on the other, or have to run right to the other side all across the map in "flat")Able to face 8 Rival Mages (so 9 players inc you), and this wonderful feature called "additional worlds". Portals in game that lead to magical worlds riddled with dangerous enemies and loots! With the possibility of 6 of these!So at max you may have 9 players, on the biggest map, with 6 additional worlds to roam to. And that's not to mention all the monsters in the game that spawn with you, the ones that spawn via random events (which can inc loot drops n such) AND Neutral Cities which act like lesser ai and are at multiple levels, so capturing isn't always easy.Other stuff in the game includes  random quests, Religious Alignment, Powerful Hero units, Spells and Spell Research and Diplomacy. Along with a multitude of different buildings for each race and appealing graphics. I feel the game runs really smooth as well, atleast on my rig.I HAVE NOT PLAYED MULTIPLAYER so i can't comment, though im sure the same settings apply, exept with other humans of course.Games can be quite long as well, even on small settings.For example im playing on the second difficulty "casual" (though i could play higher, still trying to learn the game more), on a small world, 1 enemy mage, 1 additional world and it still takes me 2 hours to win. Though you can win in probably half that, im the type of guy who likes to explore the lands and kill all the monsters and get loots and build heaps of cities and stuff, always more than i really need.I just recommend this game to anyone into Turn Based/Fantasy/RPG/4X/Strategy and even probably City Builders.I believe it has something to appeal to all and once you've gotten through your first 1 or 2 games (with very helpful tutorial tooltips which you can enable on and off, so if you forget, you can just play a normal game again and have em pop up without having to do an actual tutorial mission) you will finally start enjoying it atleast twice as much and start thinking of strats and combos and cool ways to play!I got this for free, but do i think it's worth $25? Hell. Yes. Even without a Story Mode. The amount of content and options is worth, let alone the value for multiplayer. And remember it's for the complete addition which includes the base game and 5 other content packs.So if it sounds very appealing to you, $25 would be a good investment I feel, and if you score it on any kind of sale even 25% off, bonus!

Posted: October 20, 2014
												the old microprose game, Master of magic. have you played it?if you have, like me, you would really appreciate this game. I've played a few tributes to the original, and this is one is pretty much the best of them all.very flowing gameplay, meaning it is dedicated to your pacing. lots of spells to research, and tons of manipulation you can do to the land-units, your enemies, which can be a really fun tide-turning points.I think you should be very happy playing it if you are a fan of the original like me. the mini map for combat is not there, instead its on the map itself. so part of the tactics remains.kept me enthusiastic for a few weeks. well worth the money.one thing you should keep in mind- it isn't as easy as today's games, especailly on later difficulties. which makes it much more fun. I've replayed it 3 times after seeing i have no way of winning. until i've realized the best strategy to win, that's part of the fun in the game. finding it. well at least for me.

Posted: October 21, 2014
												Having logged now 30+ hours in this game, I can speak a little bit to its greatness and some nitpicky things that are drawbacks. The game mechanics themselves are straight up great; from micromanaging your individual unit perks to keeping an eye on your macroeconomy, the process is intuitive, and once you've got the mechanics down you can optimize.Partially because of this, the game feels a little bit like "what if Civ didn't have empire size balancing." Economic advantages snowball to the point that endgames can sometimes feel like a chore. But crushing your enemies into a fine powder isn't so bad of a chore. It's considerably more of a challenge to limit yourself to a certain number of cities.Also, if you ever played the game Majesty, you'll notice many of the same gods showing up, as well as certain catchphrases. Very nice tickle of the nostalgia bone.

Posted: June 8, 2014
												Basically this game is similar to a Civ5 styled game except in a fantasy world of goblins, undead, monsters, ogres, elementals and plain old humans. Your faction is lead by a Great Mage, the research in the game unlocks spells which can be used offensively, defensively or to improve your empire in peace time e.g. population growth, food yields. City management is similar to Civ5 and the learning curve in this game is minimal. Reccomend to people whom like Civ5 but want something a little bit different.

Posted: November 27, 2016
												Remembering back to when I first played Civilization, Masters of Magic or Masters of Orion...these are the originals in many ways. Seems like as 'improvements' are made, some of the original fun became 'work'. More stats, more management, slower gameplay, more variables, more of what sometimes seems...just more of for the sake of more. Yes...sometimes deep is okay if that is what someone is looking for, but sometimes these type of games were just a distraction and that distraction became more of a job, more of a headache when that is not what was being looked for.Warlock took me back somehow....back to an enjoyable game without so much work. It seems like many try to remake a classic...and in doing so, try to add and improve it. But, the "improvements" many times change the character...the feel of the experience. It is hard to explain this formula....as it is different for different people. All I can say is that, for me, Warlock was this feel I have wanted to feel again for a long time.Does it have faults? Sure. Is it the perfect feel? Hmmm....probably not. Will something else come along? Yes. But, for a time....Warlock has been that game that I can go back to after a LONG game of Endless Lengends (Great game by the way!).And, just like past titles....they tried to 'improve' in Warlock 2....and, for me....I go back to Warlock - Master of the Arcane. If it ain't broke...don't fix it. (Well, except for bugs...some balancing...oh, and let's add...nevermind lol)

Posted: May 17, 2012
												This is my favorite strategy game ever!!!It has a better pace and combat than Civ V.The unit leveling,upgrades and enchantments feels like a RPG.I love the power of being a master warlock able to destroy things myself not just by using my units to do it.

Posted: July 17, 2012
												When Warlock was first released it seemed to me to be a disappointingly shallow 4X with diplomacy that only seemed to be in the game so they could say it was there and an annoyingly random research system.All credit to the developers they have been adding content to the game with free patches which have since added more depth, character and even online multiplay. They have done enough to raise my estimation of the game to the point that I would actually recommend it.For me, Warlock is the perfect after work slice of strategy gaming. Where Modern Manshoot 5 is just to brainless and Complicted Inaccessible Grand Strategy is too complex. Warlock sits in a comfortable niche of being accessible but thoughtful.It's not the sort of game you'd lose a weekend to though.

Posted: October 30, 2013
												It's like a magical game of Civilization.It sucked up around 2 hours of my life and I felt like I'd been playing it for only a few minutes. It's pretty good. The worlds can be extremely huge, and there is the possiblities of other worlds if you decide to go into a portal and crap.You can also hire these special units for money, I guess you can call them heroes, because they just own anything. Pretty much like a hired boss. There's also monsters on the sea!My one gripe, however, is that there really isn't a tutorial, just a bunch of hints that tell you what to do. So, by the time you build something, you wouldn't have known that you could upgrade troops with money if you have a building that lets them upgrade. And it never tells you the importance of anything, so you have to figure out everything on your own.The diplomacy is a kinda weak and you don't really feel like your creating your own sort of country/kingdom/whatever.The game is pretty much a smaller version of Civ, I'd just get that if you could afford it, but this is a really good alternative.Oh yeah, also, you can use magic and stuff from having mana, so you can heal a troop on the spot, or just kill them. Oh, even better, you can use it and raise land.And yes, you can basically make a bridge through the ocean.

Posted: March 16
												Only downside I'd like to point out is multiplayer. You have to wait other human players' turn in real time, which could take more than 5 minutes per player in mid to late game. (some other games in the genre covered this issue smoothly to make it less of a waste of time and more fun to play multiplayer.) Apart from this, there's no reason to not play this game. Armageddon DLC adds a huge and original challenge which makes already awesome game pretty flawless.DEMONS LAND NEAR YOUR BASE, BUILD A HIVE, CORRUPT THE TERRAIN TO MAKE IT IMPOSSIBLE FOR YOU TO COLLECT RESOURCES AND THEN EXPLODE ONLY TO MAKE IT ALL WORSE, SO PREPARE YOUR BODY SONBut again, that multiplayer issue bugs me.11/10 will definitely wait for my friends' turn for centuries again.

												Solid for a budget title but could have been great if they fleshed out some of the non-combat mechanics -- this undercuts three of four of the victory conditions making 'domination' the only relevant/interesting choice (and then it is simply a matter of capturing the rival capitols).  The Armageddon DLC salvages it a bit with the new victory condition of survivng waves of an invading force and ultimately requiring you to defeat a 'boss' after you've held out long enough. Posted: September 2, 2014
												I really like the world of warlock - master of the arcane. everything looks decent and the way things work is easy to understand and pretty straight forward. i keep the game installed just to return from time to time to mash up some cities with my fav undead armies. however, there are some flaws. the AI is not really intelligent to a point where it can detect a stronger foe or loosing battle and act accordingly in politics which makes the game quite easy even in harder difficulties. in addition games tend to grow quite a bit tiresome when you have to manage 20+ cities, units and events each turn but i dont have a solution myself for this yet so i wont complain.the biggest flaw in my opinion is the lack of a campaign and i dont really understand why this is the case. the framework is really good and it shouldnt be too hard to do one. in fact they decided to work on a successor instead which was not better at all so i dont really get what they are thinking. anyway warlock - master of the arcane offers a pretty solid fantasy world in which you can easily burn some hours while thinking about how to backstab your friendly allied neighbor country. 7/10!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												At first glance, this game is like Civ 5. A fantasy version of Civ 5. A half-done fantasy version of Civ 5. I was wrong and right at the same time.This game - as I just said - is pretty much a Civ 5 clone at first glance, however later on you learn that this game is not quite. With game mechanics that parallel them, this game still has plenty of other ideas, concepts and such which are completely different. The first that springs to mind are the spells.Spells are either the worst thing you in the history of ever or the best thing ever. Depends purely on which side you're on. These are an interesting - though unsurprising - element added to the game. Their near unlimited number and their wide range of effects can basically make you god-like, however these spells require mana and time to cast and if they are ongoing spells, mana for upkeep. However if you have tonnes of mana and little gold, fortunately you can just have the mass of your army be summed creatures that simply require mana for upkeep rather than gold (Some require both. Awesome...)An unusual set of elements are artefacts and lords. They randomly come about throughout the game and can be purchased/hired so long as you have enough gold to afford their upfront cost. Although you can find them in the map at various locations, I seem to find them a lot more of them to purchase at the start of the turn. The lords are a lot like their common unit counterparts, however with unique perks and abilities with the ability to equip artefacts to them to change or add more abilities. One lord got my attention and stood out from all the rest. It is - and I'm not making this up - the infamous rabbit in Monty Python and the Holy Grail. I have screencaps of it if you don't believe me. The funny thing is about this creature is that it is one of the most OP units in the game Arm the rabbit with a broomstick and it can fly, crossing all terrain with no movement penalty and the ability to take on any creature. However there are stronger lords beyond this one so [OP intensifies].The game also has pocket dimensions and they are randomly scattered through the map (supposing you have enabled them) and are infinitely useful once you managed to capture one, drive out all the late-game monsters and in general wrestle them under your control. However once one is under your control, you essentially increased the power of your empire without the further need to war with other Great Mage (players or if you don't have friends like me, the CPU). Even then, if the wars do happen, the other Great Wizards are going to go through hell to reclaim any pocket dimension.The communication and interaction with the Great Mage is fairly limited compared to those in Civ 5, with no request there being something that can have a minor result if you decline. If someone either demands resources from you or has a request, declining it can either result in outright war with the other Great Mage or destroying your alliance if it's a request. It would be great if declining wouldn't be so extreme and would simply just decrease the Great Mage's attitude towards you rather than... this. Another thing that bugs me is that either there's no option to request a war with another Great Mage or I've missed it entirely.The same applies with quests. These are also unusual game mechanics that at some times can be VERY ANNOYING! Why? Failing to complete a quest can result in a punishment. Usually they don't amount in much e.g. some gold/mana lost, but some can be kinda... dumb. For example, one god losing favour with you simply because you couldn't build a church in time. For that to happen, you need to get yourself some holy ground and if that's in anothers' land, you have to go forcibly take it from them. Something like that isn't usually done in a small space of time. Taking a city can take many turns, even with a decent, strong army. Fortunately, some quests seem to last forever so you have plenty of time to do that quest. Unless you forget the quest and do other more presssing matters at hand.Overall, Warlock is a pretty good stratergy game but could do with a bit more effort towards the interaction with other Great Mages and a bit of rebalancing with their lords.

Posted: September 10, 2014
												I ended up getting this game for free through a website promotion. The interface is clunky and not fluent at all. The game looks great and is pretty fun to play until EVERY leader demands gold and resources from you, every 4 turns. So you're practially going to war with everyone you meet right off the bat, unless you have the gold and resources to spare. This game is pretty much a spitting image of Civ5, with a few different aspects. The combat system is different, though I enjoyed the combat system in this game much more than in Civ5. You don't need workers to build stuff for you, your city automatically does it based on sufficient population of each city. Has a grind-ish aspect to it, has a large amount of monsters (barbarians) that attack your city and are placed around the world. Overall an OK game, ofcourse I got it for free so I'm not complaining.

Posted: September 10, 2014
												Absolutely brilliant fun. I got this free from Humble Bundle the other day (September 2014), and played it for the first time expecting just to have a quick look and then leave it for ages. But I'm still playing my first game, and it's still excellent.If you've ever played Civ you'll be right at home. Age of Wonders and Eador fans (among others) will also appreciate it for the fantasy armies. It's nice and easy to get into, everything is very intuitive and not over-complicated. Polished interface and detailed, crisp graphics, and a nice variety of SFX for what it is.Negatives? Well, at this early stage I might call it 'lite' strategy, although so far the AI has been robust and interesting and it's clear that this, like Civ and AoW etc, is a long-haul experience. Really, there's nothing to dislike just yet.

Posted: January 7, 2013
												I recommend you Warlock if you're a fan of Turn Based Strategy games. I play Civilization, Galactic Civilizations and more, while most of the time I go for passive/defensive victories and boost my civilization, Warlock is mostly about war, diplomacy is nice, improved, but still not very complicated, the city management has been improved too, but still pretty easy to figure out. Generally speaking, the game is easy to learn especially with previous experience and the HUD, the notifications, the info about units lets you figure out the game pretty soon, but it's still fun as hell and not so easy to master. Some say this is the spiritual successor of MoM or Age of Wonders, it does give this feel but it's easier and as said before more war based, you should focus on troops and spells to support them or some offensive spells. The game however has been continuosly fixed and improved to this day, even multiplayer has been added on 1.2! I had great fun in multiplayer, definitely one of the best additions for an already superb game. You may try the demo, which is the old version and then buy the game with the awesome DLCs and see a much more improved and polished Warlock, but yeah do try the demo, it's the one that convinced me. Oh yeah, about that war-based, you can still be passive/defensive with the unity spell which is a technoligcal/wonder victory, but the fighting is so fun even I got sucked in it.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2013
												- 8.5 / 10 -This game is truly magnificent! it's a turn-based 4X strategy / RPG-ish game in the style of the Civilization series. Yet it focuses more on action / combat & RPG-like unit leveling / upgrading, less so on civil management - it's the perfect balance between city building, resource economy & combat / leveling. The spells, heroes, unique items etc are great fun, practical & make expanding / progression both rewarding & engaging. Graphics look great & gameplay is solid & intuitive. Good tunes too.You basically assume the role of a Great Mage, build / manage an army & expand your kingdom while battling other Great Mage's, doing (or failing) quests given by various Gods - which determines a reputation rating - casting spells that rain down AOE fire-balls upon your enemies from the safetly of your castle or summoning creatures to your aid - this game has it all! It's a great system all round, gameplay is fun & the mechanics instill a sense of progressive growth. It's a truly satisfying, visceral experience. So much fun!

content:
Posted: May 19, 2012
												Usually I try not to make arbitrary comparisons, as one-liners are often not enough to explain intricate games. In this case though, I thought it might help some niches weigh off choices. Warlock takes the best element of Civilization V, namely hexes that enhance strategic gameplay. It takes the best of Civilization IV with its deities and random events. And it takes the best of Civilization Revolution, which is the much faster pace, without toning down the experience. It leans the most on the latter and is most reminiscent of fantasy title Master of Magic, but without the lighter aftertaste. Take that as you will.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												For someone like me who prefers Real-time strategy games, playing Warlock - Master of the Arcane was a very pleasant experienceI had played Civilization V before and I liked it. But for some unfortunate circumstances I couldn't get it on Steam, so I settled with this one. Turns out this game wasn't that different from Civ V, all the core elements are there, with the addition of a fantasy setting, mythological units and the ability to research and cast spells.The goal of the game is simple enough, all you need to do is to defeat the other mages in the map. To do this, however, you need to manage your cities and resources, expand your empire, explore the game's world and capture important resources, research the right spells that match your strategy, and guide your troops and upgrade them. On paper it doesn't seem different from a RTS game, but the turn-based system is a bit more tricky. Unlike RTS games, it does not emphasize on micro-management, but careful planning before making any move and having a strategy.The game has some optimization issues, the story is non-existant and the game could get a bit repititive if you don't know what you're doing. But it's still worth every penny (and seeing how the game is on sale all he time, it won't cost you much anyway)I say it's a decent alternative if you can't afford Civ V, and a good start if you want to give this genre a try without spending much on the other more famous titles.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2015
												Civ 5 with wizards.You have 3 resources, gold, food and mana. You use mana to maintain enchantments and magical units, as well as cast spells. Food goes to supporting cities and units. Gold goes to building and army upkeep, as well as buying new units.It's simpler, but still crazy addictive. There are also 'Lords', basically hero units that require a lot of upkeep but can equip artefacts and are essentially more powerful than standard units. Seriously, if you pile the enchantments on, these guys can get ridiculously OP, it's so fun.There's a religion system, where you do quests to earn favour with gods that govern particular spheres (such as death, strength or the sun). At first I thought, oh great, another list of made up deity names for me to learn, but there's not so many and they all make sense. It's especially easy to remember as they have polar opposite gods as well, e.g Dauros is the god of order and law, his rival is Fervus, god of chaos and nature.I'm not a massive strategy fan and I love this game. Fans of the 4X genre might want something more complicated, but this is a worthy buy for me.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6
												Warlock is more combat-focused than Civ, so dimplomacy and city management aren't quite as good. The fantasy elements, such as spell casting, damage types, planar travel and the pantheon of gods makes up for this. Resource management also has deeper strategy; for example, on a silver node, you must choose if you want to build a mine to gain more gold per turn, or build a forge to outfit your legions with silvered weapons to combat ethereal foes. You can manipulate the terrain with magic! How cool is that!? Lower an area into the ocean to provide passage for your navy (although naval combat can be completely ignored on most maps), or raise up mountains to provide a natural defense. Curse your foes' farmlands into a desert wasteland, or bless your own to gain increased yields. That volcano's dangerous lava flow is in your army's marching path? Freeze a safe passage through! (Disclaimer: You often can't do all of these at once. Some spells are only offered by certain gods who happen to hate eachother, so you can't be good at everything).Each faction has a primary resource focus which changes the way you play. For example, food production can be ignored by the Undead, while it is almost exclusively focused on by the Beasts. The player also controls different units based on your faction, which are further suplemented by the gods you choose to worship. Varied buffs provided by equipment, buildings and spells, and unique items coupled with the large selection of units allows a wide variety of combat strategies available. Choose from a selection of Lord units with varied upgradeable abilities to further enhance your force.The Armageddon DLC is a fun and difficult race against the clock; the squabbles of nations are inturrupted by an invasion of hell-like creatures that permanently corrupt the land. An enemy mage defeated by the invaders becomes a shade and joins their side, making it more difficult for everyone else. I wouldn't recommend enabling this on your first game. My favorite victory conditions are Conquest (kill everyone) and the Armageddon victory if you're playing with it. The Avatar victory (kill a god)  is pretty cool, but it can be cheesed, and Unity (science victory) is the best option if you're turtling, but feels rather lackluster. I'd recommend turning off the Holy Sites condition (control 50% of all holy sites), as it just gets in the way of the others. TL;DR: There's Giant Turtles.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												This is one of those games that can very easily put off first time players, with no tutorial and an extremely complicated layout that doesn't look at all user-friendly. I was indeed one of those people who was put off, so left the game alone for quite some time. But i decided to give it another and while it still took a whie to get to grips with it, i finally discovered that the game is actually fairly straightforward.This game is made by the same team who brought us the the Majesty series... visually it looks quite similar, and in terms of sound is extremely similar, thanks to the same bloke doing the voice over as he did in the Majesty games (so yes, it is the same awful Sean Connery impression). Thankfully, for those people who hate the butchery of the Scottish accent, he doesn't speak nearly as often as he does in any of the Majesty games.Given how they introduced their own unique slant on the RTS genre with Majesty you'd be forgiven for thinking they would do the same for the turn-based strategy genre here, but this time they haven't and stick with the popular turn-based formula that fans of the genre will instantly recognise. This is by no means a bad thing.Once you get past how complicated the game looks and get just half an hour of it under your belt, you'll be hooked. It's well worth persevering with as this is a great game that is certainly deserving of your time. It's also frequently included in Steam sales, so is often available at a bargain price. Pick it up during a Steam sale and you won't be disappointed at all.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 29, 2012
												Excellent strategy game that's all about conquest, leveling up your units to ridiculous levels of power and supporting them with all kinds of spells. Best dev support ever: since game release they've added Multiplayer, heroes, artifacts, a better UI, terraforming and in DLCs, a new race and the new Armaggeddon game mode.The demo has not been updated with those features so it won't give you a correct idea of the game.While people who don't have much of a strategy game culture will compare this to Civ V, developer Ino Co have been masters of hex-based strategy games for a long time, with Fantasy Wars (http://store.steampowered.com/app/63900/) and the Elven Legacy (not on Steam for the moment as its publishing deal ended) series. They basically took the kind of gameplay they know well how to do and added Age of Wonders-like spell research and city management. There is no tech tree, complex diplomacy, cultural trees, no real research besides random spell picks or any of those Civ trappings, it's mostly about warfare.My only complaints would be that the AI is not evenly challenging and that endgames can verge on the boring when you know you have the power to crush the enemy but sieging cities takes forever. And don't leave your cities unguarded, as some random events spawn powerful creatures behind your lines.All in all though, highly recommended. Looking forward to the sequel!

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												Civ meets RPG/Fantasy.Really fun 4X.Imagine you could cheat in Civ, yet it was balanced, that's Warlock. Each round, based on your mana pool, you can cast spells that influence your units or other aspects of gameplay. From increasing your food supply to levitating your infantry units so they can pass over the water.The different races have a different play style too and benefit from different priorities. If you capture cities owned by other races however, some of their unique perks can be supplied to your units. Vampires with Silver Weaponry? Why not!You can even build a multi-cultural army later on, so you're not overly hindered by your initial choices.I give it about an 8/10, just a few annoying glitches here and there (if you alt-tab out to use the internet, you get massive keyboard lag). A lot of the smaller icons Would benefit from a null space behind them as if you misclick slightly you can give out orders you did not intened to.But minor gripes. Very good game.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												The game is a TBS similar to Fantasy Wars and Elven Legacy.Good things: Dozens of different and varied spells Dozens of building types Dozens of unit typesBad things: No campaign or story mode. Only skirmishes. Lots of bugs Dumb AI Random mob spawning Some spells are overpoweredThe game is fun, but has too many downfalls to enjoy for long. My biggest concern is that the enemy player AI is really easy to beat. They don't have a strategy, they don't match attack types to defence types, and they randomly proclaim peace or war. Even on the hardest difficulty they're easily beaten.To compensate for the lack of difficulty, the game introduces random mob spawnings. The strength of these mobs seem to be random, so it's very possible that you get wiped out early in the game by a mob spawn. They can spawn anywhere and at any time, which makes it hard to create a strategy to defeat an opponent. Even worse are the Dremer, who also spawn with gates and contimate the lands. This gets really tedious after a while since there's nothing you can do about the spawning, and they just serve to increase the game difficulty in an obnoxious way.Another thing are the spells. You can resurrect any unit, but not always a hero. You can lower the land and put tough enemy units in the water, making them easy to defeat. You can cast mana drains on your enemies or erupt vulcanoes on their lands. This severely debilitates them, but they never apply these tactics to you. So after some time, the gameplay becomes the same. Slowly advance towards the enemy while dealing with the random spawns until you kill all. It gets tedious after a while, which is a shame as I really wanted to like this game.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												This game is not a Civ5 clone!!!With that out of the way, what exactly is Warlock then? The resemblances are so similar it looks like a cheap knock off, but is it? I am happy to say that the answer is no. While there are some similarites between both games, warlock focuses purely on war. You build military on a seperate queue from regular buildings, you have no workers to manage, no happiness to keep positive and by extension no luxury resources, everything you see and find is for war.You can win by owning most of the land, or researching the ultimate spell, or capturing all capital cities. Don't these victory conditions sound familiar? The only problem is, you will never have a game that lasts long enough unless you intentionally drag it out to achieve any other victory except a war/domination victory.This game begs for multiplayer, which thankfully it does have! The netcode is pretty okay too. The downside? No simultanious turns. You cannot take your turn (or seemingly do anything) while your foe takes their own turn which means that games drag on way too long! This is a game about war, I have a large military to move every single turn and so do my foes! This limits multiplayer to 1v1 because large groups are not going to finish a match in a day.Warlock is fun, the mechanics are engaging, the lore is rich and humourous in places and playing 1v1 with a friend is very stimulating. If I could rank a game as neutral then this one I would. But I can't so I can't recommend this game. One last thing, enemy AI. They are brain dead. You can win games by simply leaving the AI alone long enough to die to wild monsters. I am not even joking. They have no concept of how to play the game and certainly no idea of how to win it. If you played Civ5 and thought the AI there was bad, then that AI will seem like HAL from a space oddysey after you have seen the bone-headed bizaare AI that this game offers. The wild monsters (barbarians) are more of a threat than the actual opposing leaders.

												You're kidding me right? I cannot possibly believe that there are good reviews for this game.  It's a blatant Civ 5 rip off with half of the options and twice the design flaws. Posted: September 12, 2014
												When I was buying this game, I expected Civ 5 in phantasy setting. However what I got was a strategy game for 8-year olds. The interface is clumsy, there are ocassional freezes and half the time it doesn't really matter what choices do you make. The spells are weak or pointless and limited once per turn. The city management is basically about supporting your units and building defences and new units.I was playing this game for a while, trying to understand what it's all about. The development was taking too long and it was becoming increasingly inconvenient to overview my cities. I was getting more and more bored. And when I understood that this game is only about expansion and battles, I quit.I like researching, upgrading and building unique buildings and then crushing my enemies with powerful and well organised army. This game does offer that, but in a dull and boring way. This game focuses on unit spawning and territory expansion and it's just not enough for me.My overall rating: 5/10.

												The concept is great and thats about it. The first dozen turns or so of each game are fairly interesting but the ridiculous reward provided by just plopping down as many cities as possible and the painstaking slowness with which any interesting spells can be cast turn the late game into hours of waiting for enough money to purchase and upgrade your powerful units while you click to build the same things in 50 different towns. the main problem with the game is definetly the "population" focused cities theres essentially no way to influence your population growth substantially and yet it completely defines how many buildings you can have in each city. This combined with poor balance between spell power and the time it takes to cast it (spells that give 50% boosts to existing units combat power take 1 turn and spells that summon mediocre units take 2 as an example). Overall it's not really a BAD game but you're probably better off playing Civ V while a Harry Potter movie plays in the next room over.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
Overall description:In short: If you like other turn-based strategy games, you will like this one as well.Things it has in common with other turn-based strategy games:Randomly generated maps.Everything is on hexes.Growing cities.Settlers that build new cities.Negotiations with other Warlocks.Warships for sea battles.etc...This this game does differently, compared to other turn-based strategy games:The city upgrades are visible on the map, but can't be destroyed by enemies.You can build Forts and Magic-towers that, along with the city, can fire on nearby enemies. These two buildings can be destroyed.Each unit and hero takes up one hex on the map, you can't combine them.Each ground unit turns into its own transport ship. The ship disappears when they land.You can cast offensive, defensive, and even map-changing spells.There are alternative worlds that you can raid.Constant random map events.Not overly complicated.etc...At first, some people will feel weird with each unit taking up on hex, but you get used to it and actually learn to like it. As your troops and heroes level up, get more upgrades, and become stronger, you learn to value each unit and want to keep them alive.You research spells and harvest mana to cast them. Each spell has a mana cost, but there is also a limit on how much you can use per tern. Spells will use up a small part of what you can use per turn, a big part, all of it, or even take several turns to charge.Some of the most fun I had in this game:My enemy had a large fleet of ships that wanted to invade me. I held the beach with three melee groups, one archer group, and a healer hero that had a healing aura passive ability.I was destroying his ships before they landed and bottlenecking anything that landed. A lot of spells were used and a lot of people died... it was glorious! The guy offered resources and begged for a non aggression pact after I held the line.In another game, I kept trying to assault a guy, but I got pushed back several times because I was outnumbered. I lost a lot of heroes and a few really upgraded units. In my last push, I sacrificed two really good heroes and took two cities. Then I built forts and mage-towers between those two cities to draw the border line. I help it with Stubborn Knights, two groups of heavily upgraded Elven archers, a healer hero, a flying Elven boat, and two groups of druids. After holding the line and devastating the enemy capital with spells, all the land was cursed and filled with tentacles from all the spells. I devastated his army and blew up his capital city... I loved it.You don't really get moments like that in other games. In Total War, you have something similar during the RTS, but it's a lot more fun with spells blowing things up everywhere and randomly appearing armies.If you decide to get this game, be warned:The game is not very well optimized and there are a few bugs. The game may crash and may even freeze your computer.There are typos and it's clear that development was abandoned, but it's a fun experience. I got the game from a pack for 1$, but it may be worth buying when it is on sale.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
Overall description:In short: If you like other turn-based strategy games, you will like this one as well.Things it has in common with other turn-based strategy games:Randomly generated maps.Everything is on hexes.Growing cities.Settlers that build new cities.Negotiations with other Warlocks.Warships for sea battles.etc...This this game does differently, compared to other turn-based strategy games:The city upgrades are visible on the map, but can't be destroyed by enemies.You can build Forts and Magic-towers that, along with the city, can fire on nearby enemies. These two buildings can be destroyed.Each unit and hero takes up one hex on the map, you can't combine them.Each ground unit turns into its own transport ship. The ship disappears when they land.You can cast offensive, defensive, and even map-changing spells.There are alternative worlds that you can raid.Constant random map events.Not overly complicated.etc...At first, some people will feel weird with each unit taking up on hex, but you get used to it and actually learn to like it. As your troops and heroes level up, get more upgrades, and become stronger, you learn to value each unit and want to keep them alive.You research spells and harvest mana to cast them. Each spell has a mana cost, but there is also a limit on how much you can use per tern. Spells will use up a small part of what you can use per turn, a big part, all of it, or even take several turns to charge.Some of the most fun I had in this game:My enemy had a large fleet of ships that wanted to invade me. I held the beach with three melee groups, one archer group, and a healer hero that had a healing aura passive ability.I was destroying his ships before they landed and bottlenecking anything that landed. A lot of spells were used and a lot of people died... it was glorious! The guy offered resources and begged for a non aggression pact after I held the line.In another game, I kept trying to assault a guy, but I got pushed back several times because I was outnumbered. I lost a lot of heroes and a few really upgraded units. In my last push, I sacrificed two really good heroes and took two cities. Then I built forts and mage-towers between those two cities to draw the border line. I help it with Stubborn Knights, two groups of heavily upgraded Elven archers, a healer hero, a flying Elven boat, and two groups of druids. After holding the line and devastating the enemy capital with spells, all the land was cursed and filled with tentacles from all the spells. I devastated his army and blew up his capital city... I loved it.You don't really get moments like that in other games. In Total War, you have something similar during the RTS, but it's a lot more fun with spells blowing things up everywhere and randomly appearing armies.If you decide to get this game, be warned:The game is not very well optimized and there are a few bugs. The game may crash and may even freeze your computer.There are typos and it's clear that development was abandoned, but it's a fun experience. I got the game from a pack for 1$, but it may be worth buying when it is on sale.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												Fun fact, my review of Warlock MoA was actually one of the earlier reviews I did. Where is it, you might ask? It was lost to the void of the internet when a page got accidentally refreshed.Many months later and I’m still butthurt about losing it, I worked really hard on it because I felt the game deserved it. So here is my very very abridged version:Warlock: Master of the Arcane is a Civ knockoff. It’s not bad but it has some key flaws. The most glaring is how cumbersome the UI is. Coming from Civ is also annoying because basic shorthand like right clicking to move a unit is a completely different function. The verdict is that if you’re hard up for some Civ-like gameplay, Warlock is alright, but I personally would rather just play more Civ. The theme change doesn’t justify the feeling of having to relearn the genre.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												So many tiny things that are messed up that could have made this game great.1. Units have no auto explore. This has been a part of 4x games since Civ 3 I think. It is absurdly frustrating and time consuming to have to literally click on every unit every turn. 2. Clicking: WHY did you not use both the right and left mouse buttons? It's insane. The clicking over a unit to then do all actions with the same button is very frustrating and often leads to multiple clicks to get one action done. Also click zones are very tiny and leave you inching your mouse to get the right thing.3. Minimal control of your economy and tech tree. Basicly you have no input onto what is happening. Should I build more gold or more mana collectors, who knows. Oh I'm suddenly bankrupt, but wait, it has no effect because the next turn I'm fine. WIthout some kind of feedback into your economy/techtree the user is very disconnected from the guidance of their own civ.4. On that same note, you elminated so much of the users investment in their character by nutering the character design. I know this is just a reskinning of Master of Magic so I'm not expecting anything groundbreaking, but by removing the faction aliance to life/death/fire/air/etc you took away the special feeling of a character growing and learning a certain type of magic for a certain philosophy. Now all characters are bland and seem to take magic from all schools. 5. Never ending enemy spawn. Now I get that this is a core part of the game but it's also unnecessarily frustrating. As a builder I want the sence that I'm taking over this land and making it safer/better for my people. What's the point of me having magic walls around my cities if skeletons, vampires, and cheap humans just suddenly appear. On the same note they really don't do anything to you except attack your cities again and again and very rarely can they beat your cities ability to heal, essentially making them just a nusiance. 6. Oh last but not least, Users CAN'T SKIP ACTIONS! I don't care if some random village was built and I don't care if a sea monster is swimming past my capital. I should not have to bomb every enemy that walks by. I should have the choice.Overall I cannot recomend this game. The reskinning of MOM is long awaited and the graphics for the most part are great, though many buildings are difficult to distinguish adding another minor frustration. This game was almost good but overall I say skip it.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2016
												I bought this years ago following an RPS feature and trying the demo. It’s really good, as much fun as I rememebr the demo being: I find it hard not to have one more go. Probably because it makes it so easy to track what you need to do each turn, and the number of units hasn’t got overwhelming. My favourite game is HoMM2 – this sort of scratches a similar itch but is vastly different enough to not seem over-familiar. Also Paradox support were great (and you don’t have to create an account to contact them, unlike most companies nowadays!) I'm looking forward to trying out different options when my current game ends in inevitable victory (mwuhahaha).I’m just playing on the default settings for my first game, but have grown fond of my hero champions, slowly upgrading them as “rewards” whenever they do something successfully. Very sad when my bumbling ogre got taken down by a load of ships shooting him as he walked along the coast. I think the fact that the game doesn’t take itself too seriously is part of the charm, with units like the stubborn knights – armoured knights riding donkeys. Very Don Quixote [pun intended]. The tone is a cross between Heroes of Might & Magic, and Magicka.

												Great turn based strategy game.Very similar to Civilization in its core but has a lot of unique things to offer.almost feels like a rpg with the lords and spells and stuff.researching technologies is replaced by spells.and you can build stuff in cities when it grows instead of the worker business.With spells you can curse, buff, damage and move units.You can also change the terrain and cast stuff on rival mages.The game world can be pretty big with max 6 additional worlds which is awesome.You could almost go play this without rival mages and fight the neutrals and the mosters in the world.If you are concidering buying this or the second one id suggest the first one.The second one has stuff like unhappiness and allies share vision and bunch of other stuff I personally dont like. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												The easiest comparison is Civilization 5 with magic. Alright, review over, that was easy!Okay, really though, it LOOKS like Civ5 at first - it's a city-building game with hex tiles and units that don't stack - but it actually works fairly differently. To explain:1: There's a whole lot less focus on cities. In particular, there's not even a research tree! Each city instead has a progression of buildings it can produce and... well, to avoid getting into details, let's just say that every city is just going to specialise in producing one resource and it's nearly always obvious what to build next. It's very simple compared to Civ5.2: On the flipside, there's a whole lot more focus on military. In particular, constructing units does NOT slow down constructing buildings, instead costing their own resource (gold) to produce. And there's always wild monsters of varying toughness to kill. The end result is that, rather than in Civilization where peace is the most beneficial option, in this game EVERYONE has an army!3: Spells. There's a LOT of spells, and they do a lot of stuff - from hurting and healing to buffing and nerfing to summoning units to changing the landscape to, hell, there's even city-wide buffs in this game. Spell research is what takes over regular research in the Civ games.This is all leaving out the other big details, like heroes and gods and the nifty way you get better units. But that could go on for a while. And it's got some problems of its own because it lacks polish, things like a point where micromanagement gets annoying, and that you can't turn off animations (although you can skip them every time), and there's no synchronous multiplayer turns which it so desperately needs. The lack of polish is why I'm really looking forward to Warlock 2.But the short of it is: I really like it! On it's own, it's really not as good as Civilization 5, it just didn't have the budget to be. But if you love playing super-aggressively in it, this is a game made all about that!Oh, as for DLC? Elves adds a new race focused on research and Armageddon introduces a rather nifty man-vs-monster mode, so they're both great. And the rest... isn't worth it. Although really, if you haven't got the game yet, you should just get the Ultimate Edition, it's definitely worth the extra cost!

content:
Posted: May 13, 2012
												Yesterday I finished a match with 4 mages (1 me 3 cpu) on Large map with 3 underworld maps. It took me 12 hours, victory by conquering. Game is similiar to Civ5 - many things are similiar and some were simply copied without alterations. Although in here instead of research you have spells (that can be powerfull) and on the first plane are not towns and civilization - but heroes. They gain levels and are more powerfull and ALL buildings eiher give the ability for you to PURCHASE perks for each individual hero (not globally but micro-management) in addition to choosing traits after each level. Other buildings allow you to promote unit to more powerfull type or unlock new ones. There are 3 races: Humans, Goblins and Undead each with complete upgrade system that relies heavily on resources scattered on the map. They allow different things for different race, but play a while and you will be able to produce settlers of each nation (if you conquer their city). All majesty2 units are here :)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												As far as TBS games go, this one is terribly simple to the point of insulting to those with any experience in the genre, with AI oppenents that are simply laughable even on the hardest difficulty. City growth is pointlessly limited and constricting, not to mention slow, with games being as good as over before getting past your basic warriors. The magic system is an enjoyable power trip once you learn to use it ,then a terrifying fall back to reality when you realise the enemy can too, then back to power trip when you see that no, they really couldn't use magic to save their lives. I would recommend this game to someone new to the genre as a whole, as the game itself is fun with all the mechanics meshing together rather well with alot of room for error, and is a good judge of whether you may like the strategy genre, but for those looking for a deeper experience I would recommend they look elsewhere.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2012
												Combat-oriented turn-based strategy game structured like Civ 5. There are a 3 races (plus summoned units) and hero units which have a lot of punch with their own equip and special upgrades. Instead of research you learn spells; however, there doesn't seem to be a tree for them so it can be frustrating trying to unlock a specific spell you need. Diplomacy is really shallow and the biggest disappointment in the game for me because you can't have an allied conquest victory. The non-conquest victory conditions are really hard to complete but hopefully they will allow allied victory in the future.The devs have been hard at work on patches for Warlock and seem to really care about it. Multiplayer was added the past week along with hero units and bug fixes. If you enjoy Civ-styled games but want a fantasy twist then this is worth picking up.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												This is one of the few games I paid full price for.  I remember when it came out, I downloaded the demo and just could NOT stop playing it.  Back then the AI was quite stupid and on the hardest settings I could skip 20 turns before starting to play, and still beat it (someone else had pointed this handicap out to me as they were using it).  That has since improved, although I haven't kept up with the game's progress recently.  Still - the various races and related build options make this a great game.  Certainly worth trying the demo for yourself to see how it suits you.Cons:  The game does devolve into a click-fest after so many turns and so many units.  That would be slightly improved if city's had rally points (they don't) and other obvious improvements the developers are undoubtedly aware of.  [I've read comments to the effect Warlock 2 suffers from the same problems.]

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												A game full of promise and potential ruined by exceptionally brain dead AI, poor interface, the occasional bug, and features that make the game waaaaay too easy.Everyone seems to love Warlock. I'm not sure why. Once you know the ins and outs of the game, there's nothing to it and it becomes very boring and uninteresting. Occasionally the AI opponents will declare war on you for no reason. Occasionally monsters will randomly spawn in your territory for no reason. Often times there's zero threat and even on the harder difficulties, these messes can be cleaned up easily. Its less fun and more annoying than anything else.Warlock is in desperate need of more variety. For game that comes across as a fantasy version of Civilization, it instead chooses to ape Warcraft 3 making for a weird turn based version of it. Ripping off Civ would have worked more in its favor.Then there are other things in-game that need clean up. The spell book for instance is disorganized listing the spells in order you learned them vs alphabetically or by spell type. In fact, some of the spell descriptions need to be revised for the simple fact none of them tell you who or what it targets. Then there are also redundant spells that are slightly more powerful versions of what you already have. Would've been great if they kept it to a single spell but added a new power level to it in order to decrease disorganized clutter, but whatever.I bought this game on sale with all its DLC for $6 and pocket change, and I don't feel it was worth it. Not recommended at all.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												If you're bored by the safe, advancement-by-way-of-historic-precedent style of the Civilization games, you may find something to love in this stratigic time-sink. At every turn, you are given the oppertunity to exploit the possibilities of playing in a midevil fantansy setting. Rather than research technologies, you research spells. The map is crammed with fantasy creatures that will try to kill you. You're free to play as other races, not merely humans, and the styles of the other races carry over to thier units. Everything that has annoyed me about civilization games (too little innovation in units or setting due to prior-mentioned historic limitations, a strictly watered-down pro-western view of history in general, and lack of alternative paths to established ideas) is absent from Warlock, while the interface and presentation is as intutitve and clutter-free as Civ5. In fact, one of my few problems with Warlock is how much like Civ5 it looks and feels. Warlock is not perfect. There is a "quest" system that constantly bugs you with optional objectives that may not be helpful to you in any way, and some of them carry a price if you ignore them. In terms of diplomacy, the other races seem quick to go to war. Despite its appearence, Warlock is a game that encourages combat, so stay away if you just want to let your borders extend on their own like in Civ.If you're looking for fantasy city building + war, this may be a good game for you.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
MULTIPLAYER ONLY REVIEWReally disappointed with how big a mess attempting to player multiplayer in this is. I was looking forwards to very jolly 4X gaming, and then we have buggy help texts covering quest messages, requiring you to press Esc to close the help text that otherwise doesn't close, which also rejects the quest, as well as some bonus network desyncs. After a few hours of frustration from that and other bugs we ended up giving up. IIRC you can't even tab out of the game without issues.Also, letting people take turns at the same time or at least do *something* while the other players are doing theirs would go a long way.If you don't mind the game balance being so-so overall, it's a servicable SP game.

number of helpful: 4 of 12 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												So you know how there are B movies you can enjoy and B movies you hate?  Well, Warlock - Master of the Arcane reminds me of those B movies.There are a lot of problems: the AI is utter♥♥♥♥♥♥ may as well assume constant war with everyone...  The borders will randomly disappear or render incorrectly...  The portals to other worlds are useless because of the previously mentioned constant war...  Made units become increasingly useless as the game progresses and heroes become unstoppable killing machines that can walk through armies...  Missions are complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t because you can accept or refuse them, but refusing them makes you pay the same price as failure.  There are more problems than there are good things.At the same time, it is ridiculously silly how overpowered your heroes get, so there is a bit of enjoyment in your godslayer taking on literally every unit an enemy has.I would not recommend it to anyone, but it is not unplayable or even unenjoyable.  There are ideas that seemed interesting and there are a good number of units to toy with.  It is just really badly done.This is one of those B movies that if it is on and you're bored, well, you may get a little fun out of it.  I wouldn't recommend you buy it, but if it is playing anyway and there is nothing better to do, there are worse things to waste your time away with.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												Overall, this game is simply unimpressive, and not worth the price. This game's DOS predecessor, Master of Magic, had more mechanics despite being programmed on a much lower budget. Throw in the reality then, that this game's graphics are not top-end, and you end up with a subpar spiritual successor.There's a lot to be said for a game that lets you customize a president-wizard with chaos and holy magic and lead a nation of vampires and undead against the elven necromancers, but once the inital glee at customization wears off, the game has shallow mechanics for combat, no population happiness/revoltrisk like in other civilization games, and a meagre selection of units. Winning is just about expanding with generic "settler" units, building the same buildings, and researching a limited selection of spells. Even though there are multiple ways to win the game, they all work around this same principle: there's no real way for small kingdoms to win.If you want a fantasy civilization game, I would suggest searching for Civilization IV or V mods, or going back and playing the original Master of Magic on DOSbox.

Posted: December 5, 2013
												Awesome game. you have to like the genre before you even begin to like the game. It's a cross between age of wonders and civ. its a very agressive fast paced game with tons of combat, heros and leveling. the resourse section is simple to understand. you have gold, food and mana. this game is almost too easy to grasp. the AI is alright. some such as the dragon queen are so agressive you will almost always be at war. the combat doesn't seem like anything to special. but the beauty of the game is trying to keep soldiers alive and buffing them. nothing will make you happier then seeing a cruel creature ( a bunny) slaughter an entire enemys kingdom because they didn't have any magic. i have too many good things to say about this game. I bought it on sale for really cheap, but would buy it now if i didn't have it. depending on enemys difficulty, amount of other worlds, how agressive you are, type of world and amount of enemys, games can take a long time, but i have played an impossible AI on a small map and had it last only a couple hours. but if you go 6 impossible AI on a huge map with 6 other worlds, be prepared to have a long game. 8/10 game score

Posted: May 28, 2014
												Ever since Master Of Magic came out back durig the mid 1990's, I can't stop playig that game, even though it's over 15 years old. Over the years, many game companies have been trying to bring back or remake a lot of the original older games with modern day technology. Such games include Duke Nukem, Shadow Warrior, Wizardry 8.When I first played the game Civilization V, it was very remarkable and I had a great time playing that game. Now, they designed a game that plays just like it, only it's this game, WARLOCK. This is a fantastic remake of the classic "Master Of Magic". Although the original game company is no longer around, this is not to imply that this IS the remake, because it's not... not officially anyways. But this game comes so close to Master Of Magic, I just love this game.It plays just like Civilization V, only you also learn spells, summon monsters, and hire heroes to help you protect your kingdom and realms. With so much to do and so much more than Civilization V, you only thought that you played the best strategy game. Get ready to be a Wizard istead of a Mayor. Power in the palm of your hands, literally.

Posted: December 16, 2013
												Being a huge fan of turn-based strategy hex games like Civilization, I felt compelled to buy this amazing game. To give you a bit of backstory on this, you are basically a Great Mage that came to power in a time of great turmoil who is obsessed with expanding, conquering and any other goal associated with infinite power. The game itself has an easy to understand UI, great music (although a bit repetitive due to lack of tracks to squeeze into the hours of gameplay), good graphics and character design and other mechanics that I leave out to make this review as short as humanly possible. The heroes, however, I find to be REALLY overpowered. There's even a hero that's immune to every kind of damage imaginable, and it makes finishing the game a cakewalk. Overall, this game is very good and is definitely a must buy!

Posted: December 22, 2013
												The closest game yet to being a proper successor to Master of Magic.  Tactical battles on an overland map, city building, a variety of units that don't simply follow a rock-paper-scissors paradigm.  Terrain and unit types allow creation of choke points and standoffs and your overland spell casting helps you to overcome them.  Smooth interface, quick gameplay, and a lack of emphasis on creating a superstack and dashing around to protect/steal everything are advantages over MoM, but MoM was superior in terms of encouraging unbalanced experimental gameplay and had those fun late-game global enchantments like Armageddon and Time Stop.  Warlock has excellent options for maps and victory conditions.  The computer map generation here is very well done, essentially equal first with what MoM achieved in the industry.  Each piece of Warlock DLC adds something useful and I don't see anything that breaks the original game balance.

There are lots of different soldier types {monsters-humans} with various strengths and weaknesses that can help you out of a tough jam. Posted: September 26, 2013
												While not as deep as the Civilization series, Warlock instead emphasizes war more than diplomancy, with a huge variety of fantastical units, powers to bombard cities and armies, tile effects and natural disasters that greatly weigh the outcomes and multiple dimensions to conquor in one map to another in a single game, it makes it more unique that it's inital appearance might convey.

Posted: May 7, 2013
												I have poured quite a few hours into this game, and I can say that I enjoyed most of it.  It is a 4x hex based game (expand, explore, exterminate, and exploit), akin to Civ 5.  My very limited exposure to Civ 5 leads me to halt any more comparisons there, however I have read there are significant differences between the two games.  I've seen it most compared with Masters of Magic.The single player can be quite fun due to the interesting characters that exist within the game.  It's also got very solid gameplay and the balance isn't too bad.  The main gripe I've seen about balance is Undead and Favor to Grum-Gog, since it allows the expansion phase to be dominated by the player who chooses it and abuse the fact that Undead don't use food to spam Strong Rats, who use only food as a resource. This can also be abused in multiplayer (which is currently deserted).  Also another gripe I have is the maps are randomly generated, which for the most part is okay, but if I were to take this game super seriously and decide to be competitive, I'd want to be able to make maps to make sure they are well balanced and strategic.The base game features 3 different races that you can start off with, and each are different enough.  As you take over other towns which belong to a different race than what you start with, you can use their technologies and units to add to your army.  There are dozens of spells that are available that you can use on average once per turn, unless you use a spell that reduces casting time.  The spells range from pure damage to buffs and debuffs to units and global as well as city buffs.  There are also spells you can only get if you worship one of the eight gods, like the Summon Strong Rats I mentioned earlier.The DLC is decent, one allows you to have hero characters which you can customize with up to three items, one introduces an entire new race, and another allows for a more difficult challenge.  I'd probably get the Armageddon DLC if anything just to make the game a bit more difficult, since the AI's in this game are pretty limited.  The extra race isn't necessary, but it's unique and the hero units are really very strong and can be buffed to ridiculous levels.Also, before now there was no hope of this game going anywhere.  But there is a new subforum on the official forums for modding.  Before now, Ino-Co or somebody didn't want this to be modded at all, and in turn it pretty much killed the forum community since the game stagnated and there was no more DLC.  Though it looks like that may be reversed soon, which would be way cool.  tl;dr version: 4x game, decent balance, random maps, lots of spells, cool characters, ok DLC, currently no modding, maybe modding later. Good game.

Posted: February 6, 2014
												This is a pretty fun game.While on the surface it's clearly a Civ V clone, the added flavor of the Majesty universe really helps this game stand out on it's own. The three core playable races are interesting and different enough to add some variety and the alternate planes make it possible to expand even in the endgame. That being said, there are some problems.The diplomacy is terrible. Every demand, request, etc. only ever has two option: accept or declare war. On top of that the things that effect your standing with another Wizard/Mage/whatever are shifted heavily towards the negative. Heck one of the biggest negative impacts is "Envy of the Leader" if you, you know, actually play to win and don't putz around.Secondly, the costs are insane. The resource and upkeep costs for units (particularly elites) are massive. While the idea make sense: they're elites, you're not supposed to have a lot of them, the execution is poorly done. This also applies to certain "special" units like Elves (without the Return of the Elves DLC), Dwarves, or Minotaurs that require special buildings on unique hexes to attain. While some hex resources like Gold or Jewels can help aleviate this it takes only one Temple or a unit from them to negate any bonus. It's not uncommon for you to be in the red in terms of gold or mana income for a while until you can build cities to specialize in resources. This brings us to our next problem.The expansion of your city can take forever. Since it's so similar to Civ V I'll use that as a comparison. In Civilization you're not limited by population size when it comes to building structures in your settlements and cities and territory for upgrading resources hexes. If you have the tech, space, and hammers you can build it. This is not so here in Warlock. While the resource hexes exist and are a lot more varied than in Civ the various buildings, monuments, and wonders that are built simultaneously in the cities don't exist. This means that the only bonuses you can get for the cities are upgrades for your hexes. This would be fine except that you can only build one upgrade/building per population point. The game will give you a notification that your settlement is ready for a new structure, you assign it to be completed, and you wait for your city to grow bigger so that you can repeat the process. The whole system can be annoying especially coupled with the upkeep costs  and the rush to acquire space and resources at the beginning. You end up creating specialised cities that deal in each indiviual resource which works until something happens and the flow is interrupted and you find yourself with a big red "-30" next to your gold counter while you're at war and trying to expand or upgrade your army.All in all this fits the Paradox formula. It's a good game with a creative idea but it's kept from being great by gameplay issues. This is great if you want to play a fantasy Turn Based Strategy but if you're looking for a more in depth game that's *slightly* more balanced you're better off with a game like Civ V.

Posted: September 10, 2014
												Sooo... This game is a simplistic, fantasy themed Civ V.Nah really that's it. There's not much happening here. There are three resources to manage, three different races to play, you can kind of choose different 'civ leaders' to play but you can edit them easily because they're literally a few buffs for resource gathering and a few staring spells, you have a bunch of units whose stats are pretty straight forward and you can improve them but they don't really 'advance' other than leveling up and building improvements, your civ researches are replaced with researching new spells, there are neutral 'city-states' that you can fight and take over because there's no diplomatic options with them, there are monsters you can murder, and there are multiple worlds that function somewhat similar to the one you start on but tend to have more and higher level monsters.That's everything. That's all the game's features, right there. I might have missed one or two things but there's just not much to 'get' from this game. There isn't even a campaign, it's just skirmish or multiplayer. Having played other turn based strategy games, this one seems like it would be good for someone who's never played one before. That said, it's not bad. Everything in it is functional. You do have to have graphical options above a certain point or a lot of the game's UI features don't work, at least for me, but really it's not terribly intensive even on the higher settings.If you like turn based strategy and fantasy, this is okay. It does a lot of macro-level controls very well. If you want very precise control, or even a lot of things to manage in your turn based strategy game or, I dunno, a lot of options for things you'll probably want to find something else.
