Posted: March 2, 2014
												I absolutely recommend this game. It's a lot like Civ 5, but you can actually do things like changing the terrain, attacking with spells, buffing your dudes and so on.With the Ultimate edition, you have access to 4 races which are fundamentally different. You colonize the world civ-style, but you also have access to other dimensions that you can take over via portals. You can also raise or lower the land level, change the land type, and so on.The combat aspect is WAY better than in Civ 5, with buffs, debuffs, 5 attack types, 4 unit types (flying, aquatic, amphibious and land) and such. There is only one majow flaw: There's no hybrid turns in multiplayer. Thus, playing with a lot of people online is not recommended. However, with a small amount of friends and/or AI the game is still a lot of fun.

Posted: February 21, 2014
												absolutely amazing. But, let's go into detail as to why.Setting: A high-fantasy setting with dragons and mages and gods and stuff. (If you couldn't figure that out by the title, I feel sorry for you.)Who you play as: A master ritualist, who is able to cast spells clear across the world. You control mass armies with absolutely no minds of their own. (as standard for 4X games)Now to the jucy stuff.How optimized is it? To give you a good idea: I bought a 300 dollar laptop to be nothing but a virus-free stock trading machine, with almost no GPU or CPU power. Runs it just fine. A tad slow, but still runs fine. There is a point here, though, that I MUST  point out. You can NOT turn off animation, by what I can tell. And just about everything has god damned animations. Don't get me wrong they look really nice, and they are well-optimized...but if you could disable the animation, you could probably use a $100 laptop from 8-9 years ago to run this game. Animations, especially for a lot of simultaneous units costs quite a large deal of power.Research is not for typical technology. In fact, technology is not dependent upon research at all. Instead, it's determined by your buildings, which is somewhat odd...yet neat at the same time. Now, what your research IS for: new spells and rituals which you can then cast to either plague your enemy or grant boons to your allies.How is research done? Well, kinda standard: you select what you want to research, then wait for a set amount of time based on points required / points generated per turn. But, unlike most games which have specific tech trees, the spells you get the chance to research are relatively randomly picked, and you get a selection of 5. I think there are some basic requirements before it is in the pool of potential spells, as I never had a top-tier spell show up early on, but I did get like a lesser and a greater version of the same spell in the spell research at the same time.How's the unit selection? Well, it's damn good. Took me a good several games to play most of them, and even now, after 47.3 hours, I've yet to use some, or have them used on me (most notably the incredibly expensive dragon...which takes so long to build, and save up for, it's pretty much not worth it). There are some slightly unbalanced units, at least for their cost, but it's nothing gamebreaking, and even old trolls can be killed quite handily.There are also champions, or basically super minions that must be bought when they randomly appear. This comes from one of the DLC, and REALLY seems like an after-thought more than anything. Some are just not good for their cost, others are quite insane, and snowball so extremely that they single-handedly decimate armies and take entire towns in one shot. Now, several heroes can EVENTUALLY do that, but of course, some are just overpowered, and ramp up far too quickly.Not to mention the only way to attract them is to wait for the RNG to give you the chance to buy them. There is NO way to influence this by my experience. This is a particularly dissapointing part of the game, but, I think the other, more polished features make up for this.Graphics: I really can not comment too greatly on this, as I am no graphic critic, but they looked pretty nice. I also liked the graphic style, but that is nothing mut personal preference.AI: Can be quite punishing. I, however, was never really at any risk of losing...aside from at the very beginning...from an AI. But, they do have no problems with taking your undefended, and lightly-defended cities. The diplomacy system, however, is kinda weak, and kinda lacks a bit of the personality you would like, but it's...robust. It works. You, however, can force someone to bribe you for peace, then just continue to conquer them. I am actually ok with that, but the AI never learns that you do this, so they will keep giving you money to continue your conquest.Maps: there are several parts that make a good map, in my opinion, so I will split this up.Variety: Each map is randomly generated. So yes, it's got a good deal of variety (Screw spelling). There are also a nice, large number of different types fo tiles, and their art work is not wholely independent of eachother. If a plains is by a lava field, the lava art will leak over into the near-by tiles without changing the tile itself. Just look at the screenshots for exampls of this.Shape of tiles: Hexagonal tiles are always the best. It will always take the same number of movements to move from one tile to another, so long as you go directly there, regardless of moving diagonally or up then right or left. How easily can you tell the terrain types apart? Incredibly easily. A swamp looks nothing like a volcano or ocean, a plains looks nothing like frozen terrain. You can easily tell when tiles are seperated by rivers.(OK, my mind blanked right here. I'm going to bed, I might amend the review later when I wake up.)

Posted: January 11, 2014
												Great spiritual successor to Master of Magic. The concept is very reminiscent to Civilization although it adds a lot of unique features of its own which creates a really great 4X turn based strategy game set in a fantasy setting. You control an empire as a wizard, where you conduct research and cast spells, wage war, do diplomacy and develop your infrastructure. You can choose between 3 races that are distinct in their own way and require different playstyles. The maps are varied and filled with loot, monsters and tricky terrain. The AI is also really capable and it can be quite challenging.The graphics are marvelous for such a game and so is the soundtrack. I definitely recommend this game for anyone who is looking for an experience like Master of Magic or who want to play a game similiar to Civilization but with a fantasy twist.The only downside that I can think of right now is that there aren't that many factions to choose from and that the map generator can sometimes create really silly maps.

Posted: May 7, 2013
												I have poured quite a few hours into this game, and I can say that I enjoyed most of it.  It is a 4x hex based game (expand, explore, exterminate, and exploit), akin to Civ 5.  My very limited exposure to Civ 5 leads me to halt any more comparisons there, however I have read there are significant differences between the two games.  I've seen it most compared with Masters of Magic.The single player can be quite fun due to the interesting characters that exist within the game.  It's also got very solid gameplay and the balance isn't too bad.  The main gripe I've seen about balance is Undead and Favor to Grum-Gog, since it allows the expansion phase to be dominated by the player who chooses it and abuse the fact that Undead don't use food to spam Strong Rats, who use only food as a resource. This can also be abused in multiplayer (which is currently deserted).  Also another gripe I have is the maps are randomly generated, which for the most part is okay, but if I were to take this game super seriously and decide to be competitive, I'd want to be able to make maps to make sure they are well balanced and strategic.The base game features 3 different races that you can start off with, and each are different enough.  As you take over other towns which belong to a different race than what you start with, you can use their technologies and units to add to your army.  There are dozens of spells that are available that you can use on average once per turn, unless you use a spell that reduces casting time.  The spells range from pure damage to buffs and debuffs to units and global as well as city buffs.  There are also spells you can only get if you worship one of the eight gods, like the Summon Strong Rats I mentioned earlier.The DLC is decent, one allows you to have hero characters which you can customize with up to three items, one introduces an entire new race, and another allows for a more difficult challenge.  I'd probably get the Armageddon DLC if anything just to make the game a bit more difficult, since the AI's in this game are pretty limited.  The extra race isn't necessary, but it's unique and the hero units are really very strong and can be buffed to ridiculous levels.Also, before now there was no hope of this game going anywhere.  But there is a new subforum on the official forums for modding.  Before now, Ino-Co or somebody didn't want this to be modded at all, and in turn it pretty much killed the forum community since the game stagnated and there was no more DLC.  Though it looks like that may be reversed soon, which would be way cool.  tl;dr version: 4x game, decent balance, random maps, lots of spells, cool characters, ok DLC, currently no modding, maybe modding later. Good game.

Posted: January 22, 2014
												First of all - This game is not in any way a Civilization V clone/knock-off. This game only uses the same core elements, but all the rest is completely different.If you're into turn-based strategy games, you're definitely going to like this game. It's brilliant in every way. Though the diplomatics aren't really in-depth, the game is extremely polished. Warlock: Masters of the Arcane also has brilliant lore. Every single unit has a unique description that's written in an informative way to tell you the backstory of W:MotA.Mind you, if you want to buy this game to mainly play multiplayer, you're going to be in for a bad time. Unless you have a friend, there will most of the time be noone in the lobby.And like in every game, there are some bugs/glitches here and there, but there are only a few, and they are usually fixed with a quick restart.

Posted: July 15, 2012
												This is an awesome take on the Civilization style of game set in the Majesty universe. They even have the Majesty voice over guy. In this game, you don't really "improve" tiles. How tiles work are that the tiles within your control are able to be built on. When you build a city, you don't build the buildings "inside" the city, you build them on an available hex grid under your control. Very, very cool. Monsters get a turn! They even have Majesty style quests. BUY THIS!

Posted: November 27, 2013
												Warlock - Master of the Arcane is basically an arcade version of Civ 5 and could easily be mistaken for a Civ 5 mod. The UI is nearly a pixel-by-pixel clone of Civ 5, but the streamlined combat-oriented nature of the game speeds up the pace a bit.Wandering creatures, aka barbarians, also play a more prominent role compared to the Civ games where they cease to be a threat. Similar to HOMM, defeating monsters on the world map is key to growing your territory and consolidating your power before taking on the other great mages. Diplomacy consists of "give us stuff, or die". Unfortunately, the AI is dumb as bricks which takes away most of the challenge and pretty much kills the replayability. I usually play at Prince or lower in Civ, but I was able to beat the AI opponents in Warlock quite easily on hard; I would not recommend this game to strategy buffs. So in terms of value, it's not all that great, but it's fun for a more beat-em-up style diversion once or for people who think the Civ games are too hard or complex.

With kingdom managment and building planning being key parts to your chance at success and always keep a few units near the back of your lines cause them random encounters can make a good kingdom collapse right quick if your troops are too far back from where the problem is. Posted: April 20, 2016
												This game is really enjoyable, as a fan of the hotm and total war series I have to say this is as close as I have seen to combining them. I bought Endless Legend first and I have to say this game makes that one look so incredibly dull in comparison. The only problem I have with warlock is the difficulty, even on the highest level, impossible, it is actually pretty easy. The ai does not know how to counter spells that affect pathing, so as cool as raising a mountain range to block enemies or beaching enemy ships is the ai does not have an effective way to counter the tactic. The raise/lower land spells come early too so there is really no way to lose if you know how to use them effectively. 90% of this game is fun but the 10% that includes chasing weak enemies that flank you to attack cities or getting to a point where winning is inevitible and spending 5 hours cleaing up is not fun.Conclusion: Buy this game if it is 15 dollars or less, you will enjoy it enough to make the purchase worth it at this cost or lower.

Drop the difficulty level of the other planes allow them to be starting planes for players and the game would have more depth and greater replayabilty. Similar to HOMM, defeating monsters on the world map is key to growing your territory and consolidating your power before taking on the other great mages. Diplomacy consists of "give us stuff, or die". Unfortunately, the AI is dumb as bricks which takes away most of the challenge and pretty much kills the replayability. I usually play at Prince or lower in Civ, but I was able to beat the AI opponents in Warlock quite easily on hard; I would not recommend this game to strategy buffs. Posted: September 28, 2014
												Type: StrategySimilar to: Civilization This game can't avoid comparisons to Civ, so let's look at the differences. Warlock: * Is more focused on magical/fantasy units* Has hireable champions, after a fashion (Lords) * Has more varied NPC enemies and cities* Has enemy player AI that will actually ally up with you (revolutionary, compared to Civ V's broken diplomacy) * Has quests that feel impactful, opposed to Civ's city-state questing * Has no focus on city production; buildings and units happen in an orderly queue that's only ever several turns deepDownsides to Warlock: * Unit selection feels a little sticky, de-selecting isn't all that fluid (Civ also has this problem)* The game's a bit of a resource pig (try typing in another window while it's up) * There is nearly nothing by way of a tutorial, so get ready for reading up on forums to learn about Religions and the likeThis game is worth a play through and is probably a good pickup for strategy fans if it's in the sub-$15 range. Replay value is moderately high.

												It's a good turn based strategy game. Heavily influenced by Civs 4/5. Posted: September 23, 2014
												This game is pretty nice. Not too bad, for what I played. It's very reminiscient of the old game I had the pleasure of playing called 'Majesty: The Fantasy Kingdom Sim'. Though don't confuse the two. The playstyles of each are entirely different. The only thing in common is the game takes place possibly during the events of Majesty II, its sequel, as a war of sorts. Your goal? To conquer the lands as your chosen lord, leading your armies to conquest.You can play a variety of races, from the usual humans to bestial creatures to undead, while being able to use each one's skill to however your preferences are. After gaining enough experience with a unit, the option will be given to promote their abilities at random. This, along with the random spells you get help to make the game interesting. It never becomes too doldrum to enjoy, but it can become complicated with so much happening on-screen at once, and it'd leave the players somewhat confused. Though if you can overcome this, this is truly a unique and challenging game that I'd definitely recommend to any of my friends and any who see this comment.

Posted: September 25, 2014
												Those who remember Majesty and the remake Majesty2 will remember the dulcet Scottish "Connery-esque" tones of the advisor. This game takes the same mellieu and puts it into a full 4X game.Like all good 4X games, it can be rated on how much "just one more turn"... happens; and it does for this game. It's not Civ, but then what is?So I will only discuss the flaws. Somewhat sloppy interface; occassional lack of proper focus during NPC turns; "help" that gets you started but no further; the manual is not much better (it doesn't even have a tech-tree); graphics that slow and "judders" after a time. In short a number of niggling little flaws which detract from this being a truly excellent game. Even with these issues fixed it still wouldn't be Civ, but has many of the elements of it and is otherwise now a very solid game. Metascore underrates the current incarnation of this game somewhat.

Posted: October 1, 2014
												This game gets a 10/10 from me. It's basically Civilization V... but with MAGIC... dragons, gods, mythology, wizards, and monsters. Need I say more? Well here's more:-The graphics... holy cow the fidelity! So vivid, lush and vibrant! Some of the most beautiful environments I have ever seen. Care was even placed into animating city borders. Everything comes together to seriously make you feels that the world you're playing in is filled with magic.-The combat in this game completely blows the Civ5 combat system out of the water. Your units can continue leveling indefinitely and gain permanent buffs from the spells you cast upon them. As a result you end up caring about your units and start to grow with them through the ages. They each become quite formidable in their own right. That archer you started out with on turn 1? Well guess what, he's fighting an immortal god now on turn 80 because you kept investing in him. -There are randomly generating events happening all over the world that affects all players, which is absolutely awesome. You're fighting not just on land and sea but in other dimensions and planetary planes. There is also huge replay ability through the randomly generated maps, and the versatility in which you can play your wizard. Do you want to create the most powerful cities the world has ever seen? Or do you want your units to take on gods? Or would you rather amass the greatest army or navy? Or just burn everyone with your magic!-The units you can build are based upon your environment... that's right... you can potentially get different types of armies every game! You are no longer tied down to your race or class but can scour the world seeking elves, werewolf, or dragon turtles.-The interface looks absolutely breath taking. Someone put a lot of love and care into designing an extremely immersive interface.Cons:-Unit controls and deselection sometimes executes commands you did not intend.-There is no visible tech tree for spells, which I'd imagine is quite extensive, you end up praying for the spell you want.

Posted: July 22, 2013
												Warlock: Master of the Arcane Reviewby DaniAngione----------------------------Art - 8 / 10Sound - 8 / 10Gameplay - 8 / 10Emotional - 7 / 10Community - 7 / 10----------------------------Overall - 7.6----------------------------** Check my profile to understand my scoring system**If you like the Civilization series and the Heroes of Might and Magic series AND competitive multiplayer, this might be the perfect game for you. This title could easily be given to Fallen Enchantress IF it had multiplayer. Since it has not, Warlock is (so far) the best Civ-slash-Heroes mash-up you can get. (Rumour is that Fallen Enchantress will be getting multiplayer soon(tm))The game plays pretty much like Civilization. In fact it's so identical to Civilization V that I suspect the engine might even be the same (although I couldn't find that info anywhere) so if you're a Civilization V player and likes fantasy, that's probably a must-have. However it's a really limited game. There aren't as many units and nations like you have in Civilization, so variety isn't a plus here. But when it comes to gameplay, Warlock offers several features that are really neat and interesting. Levelling units feel a lot more rewarding than doing so on Civ, since you have many more perks to give them. And the advantages/disadvantages between units are much more clear and functional. City building is fantastic - you really snap buildings into map tiles (hexagons) and there are buildings that have map funcionalities. So if you have a city that's near a mountain pass, you can place a castle on the pass and force invaders to defeat the castle before getting to the city tile. Admitting heroes into your nation feels like the old Master of Orion games and plays like a simplified version of heroes - but it's really enjoyable to see your heroes leading your armies into conquering towns, levelling them and grabbing some shiny gear.Some gameplay features like different planes and the apocalypse game mode (which spawns hell gates, something pretty much like what happens in TES: Oblivion) give it a charm.It's not the best strategy game out there - but certainly can be the best choice if you're looking for some grand-strategy with a fantasy setting.

Posted: February 21, 2014
												absolutely amazing. But, let's go into detail as to why.Setting: A high-fantasy setting with dragons and mages and gods and stuff. (If you couldn't figure that out by the title, I feel sorry for you.)Who you play as: A master ritualist, who is able to cast spells clear across the world. You control mass armies with absolutely no minds of their own. (as standard for 4X games)Now to the jucy stuff.How optimized is it? To give you a good idea: I bought a 300 dollar laptop to be nothing but a virus-free stock trading machine, with almost no GPU or CPU power. Runs it just fine. A tad slow, but still runs fine. There is a point here, though, that I MUST  point out. You can NOT turn off animation, by what I can tell. And just about everything has god damned animations. Don't get me wrong they look really nice, and they are well-optimized...but if you could disable the animation, you could probably use a $100 laptop from 8-9 years ago to run this game. Animations, especially for a lot of simultaneous units costs quite a large deal of power.Research is not for typical technology. In fact, technology is not dependent upon research at all. Instead, it's determined by your buildings, which is somewhat odd...yet neat at the same time. Now, what your research IS for: new spells and rituals which you can then cast to either plague your enemy or grant boons to your allies.How is research done? Well, kinda standard: you select what you want to research, then wait for a set amount of time based on points required / points generated per turn. But, unlike most games which have specific tech trees, the spells you get the chance to research are relatively randomly picked, and you get a selection of 5. I think there are some basic requirements before it is in the pool of potential spells, as I never had a top-tier spell show up early on, but I did get like a lesser and a greater version of the same spell in the spell research at the same time.How's the unit selection? Well, it's damn good. Took me a good several games to play most of them, and even now, after 47.3 hours, I've yet to use some, or have them used on me (most notably the incredibly expensive dragon...which takes so long to build, and save up for, it's pretty much not worth it). There are some slightly unbalanced units, at least for their cost, but it's nothing gamebreaking, and even old trolls can be killed quite handily.There are also champions, or basically super minions that must be bought when they randomly appear. This comes from one of the DLC, and REALLY seems like an after-thought more than anything. Some are just not good for their cost, others are quite insane, and snowball so extremely that they single-handedly decimate armies and take entire towns in one shot. Now, several heroes can EVENTUALLY do that, but of course, some are just overpowered, and ramp up far too quickly.Not to mention the only way to attract them is to wait for the RNG to give you the chance to buy them. There is NO way to influence this by my experience. This is a particularly dissapointing part of the game, but, I think the other, more polished features make up for this.Graphics: I really can not comment too greatly on this, as I am no graphic critic, but they looked pretty nice. I also liked the graphic style, but that is nothing mut personal preference.AI: Can be quite punishing. I, however, was never really at any risk of losing...aside from at the very beginning...from an AI. But, they do have no problems with taking your undefended, and lightly-defended cities. The diplomacy system, however, is kinda weak, and kinda lacks a bit of the personality you would like, but it's...robust. It works. You, however, can force someone to bribe you for peace, then just continue to conquer them. I am actually ok with that, but the AI never learns that you do this, so they will keep giving you money to continue your conquest.Maps: there are several parts that make a good map, in my opinion, so I will split this up.Variety: Each map is randomly generated. So yes, it's got a good deal of variety (Screw spelling). There are also a nice, large number of different types fo tiles, and their art work is not wholely independent of eachother. If a plains is by a lava field, the lava art will leak over into the near-by tiles without changing the tile itself. Just look at the screenshots for exampls of this.Shape of tiles: Hexagonal tiles are always the best. It will always take the same number of movements to move from one tile to another, so long as you go directly there, regardless of moving diagonally or up then right or left. How easily can you tell the terrain types apart? Incredibly easily. A swamp looks nothing like a volcano or ocean, a plains looks nothing like frozen terrain. You can easily tell when tiles are seperated by rivers.(OK, my mind blanked right here. I'm going to bed, I might amend the review later when I wake up.)

Posted: February 6, 2014
												This is a pretty fun game.While on the surface it's clearly a Civ V clone, the added flavor of the Majesty universe really helps this game stand out on it's own. The three core playable races are interesting and different enough to add some variety and the alternate planes make it possible to expand even in the endgame. That being said, there are some problems.The diplomacy is terrible. Every demand, request, etc. only ever has two option: accept or declare war. On top of that the things that effect your standing with another Wizard/Mage/whatever are shifted heavily towards the negative. Heck one of the biggest negative impacts is "Envy of the Leader" if you, you know, actually play to win and don't putz around.Secondly, the costs are insane. The resource and upkeep costs for units (particularly elites) are massive. While the idea make sense: they're elites, you're not supposed to have a lot of them, the execution is poorly done. This also applies to certain "special" units like Elves (without the Return of the Elves DLC), Dwarves, or Minotaurs that require special buildings on unique hexes to attain. While some hex resources like Gold or Jewels can help aleviate this it takes only one Temple or a unit from them to negate any bonus. It's not uncommon for you to be in the red in terms of gold or mana income for a while until you can build cities to specialize in resources. This brings us to our next problem.The expansion of your city can take forever. Since it's so similar to Civ V I'll use that as a comparison. In Civilization you're not limited by population size when it comes to building structures in your settlements and cities and territory for upgrading resources hexes. If you have the tech, space, and hammers you can build it. This is not so here in Warlock. While the resource hexes exist and are a lot more varied than in Civ the various buildings, monuments, and wonders that are built simultaneously in the cities don't exist. This means that the only bonuses you can get for the cities are upgrades for your hexes. This would be fine except that you can only build one upgrade/building per population point. The game will give you a notification that your settlement is ready for a new structure, you assign it to be completed, and you wait for your city to grow bigger so that you can repeat the process. The whole system can be annoying especially coupled with the upkeep costs  and the rush to acquire space and resources at the beginning. You end up creating specialised cities that deal in each indiviual resource which works until something happens and the flow is interrupted and you find yourself with a big red "-30" next to your gold counter while you're at war and trying to expand or upgrade your army.All in all this fits the Paradox formula. It's a good game with a creative idea but it's kept from being great by gameplay issues. This is great if you want to play a fantasy Turn Based Strategy but if you're looking for a more in depth game that's *slightly* more balanced you're better off with a game like Civ V.

Posted: July 22, 2013
												Warlock: Master of the Arcane Reviewby DaniAngione----------------------------Art - 8 / 10Sound - 8 / 10Gameplay - 8 / 10Emotional - 7 / 10Community - 7 / 10----------------------------Overall - 7.6----------------------------** Check my profile to understand my scoring system**If you like the Civilization series and the Heroes of Might and Magic series AND competitive multiplayer, this might be the perfect game for you. This title could easily be given to Fallen Enchantress IF it had multiplayer. Since it has not, Warlock is (so far) the best Civ-slash-Heroes mash-up you can get. (Rumour is that Fallen Enchantress will be getting multiplayer soon(tm))The game plays pretty much like Civilization. In fact it's so identical to Civilization V that I suspect the engine might even be the same (although I couldn't find that info anywhere) so if you're a Civilization V player and likes fantasy, that's probably a must-have. However it's a really limited game. There aren't as many units and nations like you have in Civilization, so variety isn't a plus here. But when it comes to gameplay, Warlock offers several features that are really neat and interesting. Levelling units feel a lot more rewarding than doing so on Civ, since you have many more perks to give them. And the advantages/disadvantages between units are much more clear and functional. City building is fantastic - you really snap buildings into map tiles (hexagons) and there are buildings that have map funcionalities. So if you have a city that's near a mountain pass, you can place a castle on the pass and force invaders to defeat the castle before getting to the city tile. Admitting heroes into your nation feels like the old Master of Orion games and plays like a simplified version of heroes - but it's really enjoyable to see your heroes leading your armies into conquering towns, levelling them and grabbing some shiny gear.Some gameplay features like different planes and the apocalypse game mode (which spawns hell gates, something pretty much like what happens in TES: Oblivion) give it a charm.It's not the best strategy game out there - but certainly can be the best choice if you're looking for some grand-strategy with a fantasy setting.

Posted: September 10, 2014
												Sooo... This game is a simplistic, fantasy themed Civ V.Nah really that's it. There's not much happening here. There are three resources to manage, three different races to play, you can kind of choose different 'civ leaders' to play but you can edit them easily because they're literally a few buffs for resource gathering and a few staring spells, you have a bunch of units whose stats are pretty straight forward and you can improve them but they don't really 'advance' other than leveling up and building improvements, your civ researches are replaced with researching new spells, there are neutral 'city-states' that you can fight and take over because there's no diplomatic options with them, there are monsters you can murder, and there are multiple worlds that function somewhat similar to the one you start on but tend to have more and higher level monsters.That's everything. That's all the game's features, right there. I might have missed one or two things but there's just not much to 'get' from this game. There isn't even a campaign, it's just skirmish or multiplayer. Having played other turn based strategy games, this one seems like it would be good for someone who's never played one before. That said, it's not bad. Everything in it is functional. You do have to have graphical options above a certain point or a lot of the game's UI features don't work, at least for me, but really it's not terribly intensive even on the higher settings.If you like turn based strategy and fantasy, this is okay. It does a lot of macro-level controls very well. If you want very precise control, or even a lot of things to manage in your turn based strategy game or, I dunno, a lot of options for things you'll probably want to find something else.

Posted: July 17, 2014
												This game is great. It seems like this game is more "accessible" than Civilization. A hexagonal, turn-based Strategy game where you build towns and conquer them, as well as expand them or raise an army.Set in a fantasy world where you, a mage, can cast spells, command troops, and build, as well as, expand your citires. The spells you can cast can be to rain fire upon foes, heal a unit, aid your city, or change the landscape. Troops you command range from hand-to-hand troops, ships, archers, wolves, etc.The reasorces you need are Coin/money, food, mana, and knowledge. Also, to build a structure, a city must have the needed population for it. You can build unites even though some cities may not have enough food, but still important to have food, as well as coin, to upkeep a unit. IMana is needed to upkeep some buildings, and to cast spells. There is a list of spells that can be researched and a list of buildings that can be built. You can use several mages, some are human, some are monsters/beast, and finally demons. It is mostly for the type of spells or bonuses you get for using a specific mage. One mage, for instance, aids more with healing units.You can conquer ciities from other mages, or other cities scattered about. There are random enemies that hold no alliegience to any mage and they are a cool, and sometimes annoying, groupd of enemies.You can make peace or forge an alliance, and brake the allience or end peace time. There are main worlds within a game single playthrough, and there are side worlds which you can conquer or avoid.I highly recommend this to the people looking for a Civilization-style game, and to those looking to try something new. Play the Demo and see for yourself.

Posted: December 17, 2014
												I had high hopes for this game. I thought it might be somewhat similar to XCOM, which was my first foray into turn-based strategy games. No such luck. Warlock - Master of the Arcane has no story, clunky controls, annoying voice-overs, cliche lore, and is painfully sexist. There is apparently no real campaign, just quests that randomly appear. The controls work some of the time, and there is no menu to map controls to different keys. The voice acting is stilted at best, and tends to be jarring. Play is slow and uninteresting. Out of all the character options (~12) there are two females - a healer and a dragon queen. There's no female undead character, or a female battle-mage, which was extremely disappointing. The only redeeming qualities? Well, the graphics are nice enough, but the best thing is I got this for free in a humble bundle, so I can throw this abysmal excuse for a strategy game away with no regrets. 2/10

												This game is pretty nice. Not too bad, for what I played. It's very reminiscient of the old game I had the pleasure of playing called 'Majesty: The Fantasy Kingdom Sim'. Though don't confuse the two. The playstyles of each are entirely different. The only thing in common is the game takes place possibly during the events of Majesty II, its sequel, as a war of sorts. Your goal? To conquer the lands as your chosen lord, leading your armies to conquest.You can play a variety of races, from the usual humans to bestial creatures to undead, while being able to use each one's skill to however your preferences are. After gaining enough experience with a unit, the option will be given to promote their abilities at random. This, along with the random spells you get help to make the game interesting. It never becomes too doldrum to enjoy, but it can become complicated with so much happening on-screen at once, and it'd leave the players somewhat confused. Posted: September 28, 2014
												Type: StrategySimilar to: Civilization This game can't avoid comparisons to Civ, so let's look at the differences. Warlock: * Is more focused on magical/fantasy units* Has hireable champions, after a fashion (Lords) * Has more varied NPC enemies and cities* Has enemy player AI that will actually ally up with you (revolutionary, compared to Civ V's broken diplomacy) * Has quests that feel impactful, opposed to Civ's city-state questing * Has no focus on city production; buildings and units happen in an orderly queue that's only ever several turns deepDownsides to Warlock: * Unit selection feels a little sticky, de-selecting isn't all that fluid (Civ also has this problem)* The game's a bit of a resource pig (try typing in another window while it's up) * There is nearly nothing by way of a tutorial, so get ready for reading up on forums to learn about Religions and the likeThis game is worth a play through and is probably a good pickup for strategy fans if it's in the sub-$15 range. Replay value is moderately high.

Posted: February 7, 2015
												This one positively surprised me. Got this for free during the Humble Bundle thing and had a great time with it ever since. Warlock - Master of the Arcane is a turn based strategy game about a warlock (surprise, surprise!) battling his colleagues in an epic battle for a world filled with Gods, parallel worlds, and more monsters than you can count. The game itself shows a clear influence from the Age of Wonders series. Research spells and unleash them to grant your troops new abilities, weaken and damage your enemies, or change the face of the world around you. Water blocking your way? Raise the land and create a passage for your troops that doesn't put them at the mercy of naval monsters! Mountains slowing down your troops? Flatten them. The mountains, not the troops. Just make sure you have the mana to sustain all your permanent spells. There is little as terrifying as a flying ogre with a vampiric regeneration and an area attack.Mana, as well as gold and food (your main resources) are generated by city buildings. You can found or capture cities, although make sure they have enough room to grow. Place them near strategic resources for some special buildings, depending on the faction that lives in your city - the undead will utilise a pumkin patch different than humans would. Depending on which buildings you have, you can purchase powerful upgrades for your troops, ranging from a slight defense bonus to health regeneration each turn. They will also gain experience from battles, and you may choose an improvement with every levelup as well. Battles are fairly simple. Move your troops on the hex of the enemy you wish to attack, and they automatically fight. Damage is determined by the health of your troops (full health = max strength), as well as their damage type and the enemy defense. Heroes on either side, like the aforementioned flying ogre, might turn the tide of a battle, and placing your troops in cities or on mountains might give you the edge you need. Randomly given quests by Gods, guilds or an advisor will offer you some short to middle term objectives and keep you busy for a bit, as you wouldn't want to anger a God. Especially the Divine missions often offer a great reward as well, be it a spell or a troop tied to that particular deity. You wouldn't want to miss out on those now, would you?All in all a great game with a lot of unit variety, customiseability and a weird sense of humour. One minor issue, though... please don't use Google Translator for in game text. I originally installed the german version, and promptly found some rather glaring issues with that (Close was basically translated to 'near city view' as opposed to 'close that window', for example). Luckily, Steam allowed me to easily switch to english.

Posted: November 13, 2014
												Master of Magic meets Civilization 5 and the result is pretty good. There is some problems with details, but overall it works. I'm going to make a lot of references to Master of Magic (MoM) because I love that 20 years old game and this one reminds me of it in a good way. For example:The research system is reserved to spells, but there is a tech tree of sorts to the units too: In order to build units you need buildings and more advanced buildings for more advanced units. To build the advanced buildings you need to have the basic buildings first. The difference to MoM is that the buildings occupy hexes and there isn't necessarily room to build everything... until you learn the landscaping spells to make more room, that is.MoM had the other world besides the main map: Myrror. In this game there can be several alternate worlds, though they are smaller than the main map. They are not as developed as Myrror, only filled with dangerous monsters. Also there seems to be only one portal to each, which could be a bottleneck.The different races with unique buildings and units, though this game has only 4, while MoM had 14.This game also adds to the mix a parthenon of deities, which is a pretty standard thing in fantasy literature, but usually missing in these games. There are divine spells, which are mostly slightly powerful or a bit easier to cast versions of regular spells, that you can only research and cast if you are in favor of that deity. You can gain favor by doing quests and building temples on the holy ground. While you bow down to one god, you show your backside the opposite god. One way to win the game is to get one god so angry that it manifests on the map and then destroy it. Religion also affects the relationships between the wizards. It's a nice system.Speaking of quests, they kind of suck. You just get some random build this building/found a city/kill these random enemies that popped up here/capture this city/defeat this player that just pops up. Same with random events being just monster lairs popping up on your lands. Definitely the weakest part of this game. MoM's events had much more style. Some might argue that the AI not being able to handle the complexities could be a bigger problem. I didn't play enough to be sure, but it seemed to be struggling with it. Not worse than Civ 5, but in this game it has to handle with the parallel worlds, terrain changing by spells and stuff like that too.All in all a very nice concept that could use some tweaking and filling out the content to be really great. I'm glad I got this free from Humble Bundle. Made me put Warlock II high on my wishlist.

Posted: November 29, 2013
												This is where I wish reviews had a 'Meh' or "Neutral" or a "Maybe" option(s): Warlock is, on its face, a Civ 5 clone with many interesting features. Closest I can make for an anology would be Lords of the Realm or Lords of Magic, brought into the Civ5 graphical engine and gameplay. It is hard as hell to play . Don't DARE go into the other universes without the understanding that even the friendliest is Dark Souls level difficult. But if the guardians of the portals don't lend to this than you are more hearty than I. Play this if you want a tatical combat challenge. If you're more a city builder, hit up Civ5 (or earlier).

Posted: November 16, 2014
												On one hand, you could call this game fantasy Civ V and leave it at that. And you'd be pretty accurate.On the other, you could call it a surprisingly deep and funny hex-based grand strategy game with clever tongue-in-cheek flavor text and voicing to back up a fast-paced, engaging, and interesting gameplay that will always leave you with plenty on your plate to work on and plenty to look forward to until the moment you win.You will probably never run out of world to explore, even after searching most of the primary map, since the best resources are off in the distance, hiding, and the alternate worlds have even better loot to find, and you will probably never be able to dedicate as much of your resources as you'd like to exploring, because there are always monsters or angy neighbors on your doorstep just waiting to punch you in the face when you aren't looking.While it puts just a little much value in the city-spam, Warlock is a fiendishly fun and interesting game that is yes, like Civ, but also independent of it in character and style. And is extremely fun.

My own laptop can usually handle some pretty high-end games on low settings, but Warlock started freezing up and eventually crashed late into one of my matches against the AI. 												Got the main game for free from the Humble Store then bought all the DLCs at 75% off here on Steam.  I've spent 28+ game hours and so far, I am still very much fond of playing Warlock.  This was released in 2012 but the graphics is still very good. The gameplay reminded me of the classic "Master of Magic" from Microprose and of course of "Sid Meier's Civilization" series.  "Warlock: Master of the Arcane" isn't without fault though as I experienced a crash or two... but still, I haven't felt this excited again to play a game for so long until now.  This one is very absorbing and quite addictive.  It is truly superb value if you can find it on sale else I suggest just getting the second iteration: "Warlock 2: The Exiled".

Posted: November 8, 2014
												If you like turn based 4X and fantasy this is a pretty fun game to dump some time into.  It shares some elements with Civ5, Heroes of Might and Magic and of course Majesty.  Diplomacy is a little lacking and schizophrenic so it's really war heavy, I've found it necessary to constantly sign and resign non-aggression pacts in order to stay at peace when my army's busy clearing another realm for expansion.   The spellcasting is a really neat element though and a lot of fun to play with especially the terraforming spells.  Need a land bridge between continents?  Raise one.  Farms not producing in your frozen tundra?  Make the land fertile.  Don't be afraid to enchant away either, the upkeep really isn't bad considering how much mana you eventually bring in.  The difficulty is a little on the weak side though and once you get the hang of the mechanics  it's not really challenging in the long run, then again that's a problem most 4X games have so I wouldn't let that influence things much.

Posted: December 16, 2013
												Being a huge fan of turn-based strategy hex games like Civilization, I felt compelled to buy this amazing game. To give you a bit of backstory on this, you are basically a Great Mage that came to power in a time of great turmoil who is obsessed with expanding, conquering and any other goal associated with infinite power. The game itself has an easy to understand UI, great music (although a bit repetitive due to lack of tracks to squeeze into the hours of gameplay), good graphics and character design and other mechanics that I leave out to make this review as short as humanly possible. The heroes, however, I find to be REALLY overpowered. There's even a hero that's immune to every kind of damage imaginable, and it makes finishing the game a cakewalk. Overall, this game is very good and is definitely a must buy!

Posted: December 22, 2013
												The closest game yet to being a proper successor to Master of Magic.  Tactical battles on an overland map, city building, a variety of units that don't simply follow a rock-paper-scissors paradigm.  Terrain and unit types allow creation of choke points and standoffs and your overland spell casting helps you to overcome them.  Smooth interface, quick gameplay, and a lack of emphasis on creating a superstack and dashing around to protect/steal everything are advantages over MoM, but MoM was superior in terms of encouraging unbalanced experimental gameplay and had those fun late-game global enchantments like Armageddon and Time Stop.  Warlock has excellent options for maps and victory conditions.  The computer map generation here is very well done, essentially equal first with what MoM achieved in the industry.  Each piece of Warlock DLC adds something useful and I don't see anything that breaks the original game balance.

Posted: November 16, 2014
												On one hand, you could call this game fantasy Civ V and leave it at that. And you'd be pretty accurate.On the other, you could call it a surprisingly deep and funny hex-based grand strategy game with clever tongue-in-cheek flavor text and voicing to back up a fast-paced, engaging, and interesting gameplay that will always leave you with plenty on your plate to work on and plenty to look forward to until the moment you win.You will probably never run out of world to explore, even after searching most of the primary map, since the best resources are off in the distance, hiding, and the alternate worlds have even better loot to find, and you will probably never be able to dedicate as much of your resources as you'd like to exploring, because there are always monsters or angy neighbors on your doorstep just waiting to punch you in the face when you aren't looking.While it puts just a little much value in the city-spam, Warlock is a fiendishly fun and interesting game that is yes, like Civ, but also independent of it in character and style. And is extremely fun.

Posted: December 13, 2015
												Every review of this game mentions the Civilization series, and since I just did, this will be no different. This game is basically Civilization, with a fantasy setting. The tech trees are replaced with spell research, which is probably the weakest part of the game. Some of the spell ideas are great, like the ability to change terrain to different types to either boost your cities or mess with opponents. For the most part though, it feels like a bit of a pointless endeavour. In general though, it's a solid 4X game, which I've put a lot of time into. There's enough that's new about it to keep it interesting, and the gameplay is solid and fun enough to feel classic.

Posted: November 27, 2013
												Warlock - Master of the Arcane is basically an arcade version of Civ 5 and could easily be mistaken for a Civ 5 mod. The UI is nearly a pixel-by-pixel clone of Civ 5, but the streamlined combat-oriented nature of the game speeds up the pace a bit.Wandering creatures, aka barbarians, also play a more prominent role compared to the Civ games where they cease to be a threat. Similar to HOMM, defeating monsters on the world map is key to growing your territory and consolidating your power before taking on the other great mages. Diplomacy consists of "give us stuff, or die". Unfortunately, the AI is dumb as bricks which takes away most of the challenge and pretty much kills the replayability. I usually play at Prince or lower in Civ, but I was able to beat the AI opponents in Warlock quite easily on hard; I would not recommend this game to strategy buffs. So in terms of value, it's not all that great, but it's fun for a more beat-em-up style diversion once or for people who think the Civ games are too hard or complex.

Posted: January 12, 2015
												This is an excellent Civilization clone in a fantasy setting, slightly similar to the old Master of Magic, but much more varied. I'm not sure why other reviewers are comparing it to HOMM and its clones, I don't think it really is like them at all.The exploration and conquest are mostly open-ended, you are fighting generic fantasy enemies without any specific goals or personalities, just for the sake of conquering them, just like in any Civ game. Unfortunately the AI lags behind the rest of the game quality-wise. It is rather predictable and tends to make stupid decisions. There are also bugs that should have long been corrected, especially the interface becoming unusable because of a pop-up window that can't be closed properly. Right, there is an easy workaround, but this is no excuse for not fixing a bug. Otherwise the user interface is exactly what you would expect in a Civ game, very functional and comfortable. The graphics are excellent as well. I wouldn't recommend buying it at its full price, but it has been included in many bundles and even given away for free on various occasions. I think it's definitely worth picking up for a few dollars when given the chance.

Posted: November 13, 2014
												Master of Magic meets Civilization 5 and the result is pretty good. There is some problems with details, but overall it works. I'm going to make a lot of references to Master of Magic (MoM) because I love that 20 years old game and this one reminds me of it in a good way. For example:The research system is reserved to spells, but there is a tech tree of sorts to the units too: In order to build units you need buildings and more advanced buildings for more advanced units. To build the advanced buildings you need to have the basic buildings first. The difference to MoM is that the buildings occupy hexes and there isn't necessarily room to build everything... until you learn the landscaping spells to make more room, that is.MoM had the other world besides the main map: Myrror. In this game there can be several alternate worlds, though they are smaller than the main map. They are not as developed as Myrror, only filled with dangerous monsters. Also there seems to be only one portal to each, which could be a bottleneck.The different races with unique buildings and units, though this game has only 4, while MoM had 14.This game also adds to the mix a parthenon of deities, which is a pretty standard thing in fantasy literature, but usually missing in these games. There are divine spells, which are mostly slightly powerful or a bit easier to cast versions of regular spells, that you can only research and cast if you are in favor of that deity. You can gain favor by doing quests and building temples on the holy ground. While you bow down to one god, you show your backside the opposite god. One way to win the game is to get one god so angry that it manifests on the map and then destroy it. Religion also affects the relationships between the wizards. It's a nice system.Speaking of quests, they kind of suck. You just get some random build this building/found a city/kill these random enemies that popped up here/capture this city/defeat this player that just pops up. Same with random events being just monster lairs popping up on your lands. Definitely the weakest part of this game. MoM's events had much more style. Some might argue that the AI not being able to handle the complexities could be a bigger problem. I didn't play enough to be sure, but it seemed to be struggling with it. Not worse than Civ 5, but in this game it has to handle with the parallel worlds, terrain changing by spells and stuff like that too.All in all a very nice concept that could use some tweaking and filling out the content to be really great. I'm glad I got this free from Humble Bundle. Made me put Warlock II high on my wishlist.

Posted: May 28, 2014
												Ever since Master Of Magic came out back durig the mid 1990's, I can't stop playig that game, even though it's over 15 years old. Over the years, many game companies have been trying to bring back or remake a lot of the original older games with modern day technology. Such games include Duke Nukem, Shadow Warrior, Wizardry 8.When I first played the game Civilization V, it was very remarkable and I had a great time playing that game. Now, they designed a game that plays just like it, only it's this game, WARLOCK. This is a fantastic remake of the classic "Master Of Magic". Although the original game company is no longer around, this is not to imply that this IS the remake, because it's not... not officially anyways. But this game comes so close to Master Of Magic, I just love this game.It plays just like Civilization V, only you also learn spells, summon monsters, and hire heroes to help you protect your kingdom and realms. With so much to do and so much more than Civilization V, you only thought that you played the best strategy game. Get ready to be a Wizard istead of a Mayor. Power in the palm of your hands, literally.

Posted: May 23, 2014
												A surprising gem!  I got this as part of a bundle without knowing anything about it at all, and was pleasantly surprised.  It's a hex-based strategy game which is realtively light, and whose mechanics keep it tight the whole way through.  The gameplay is sort of like Civilization 5 minus Civilization 4 - city building and resources are dealt with in a minimalist style, and the hex-based combat has a similar feel to the best of Civ 5, with an expanded system for damage types.  It also has an overland magic system that will remind you of Master of Magic.  Apart from tight mechanics, this game is also very colourful - visually appealing with an entertaining roster of units, and a sense of humour which isn't forced or overlaboured.  The only real downside is that the animations are too long, and you need to skip them to play at any rate - doubly bad as that detracts from the atmosphere and also gives you RSI.  Would still strongly recommend if you're looking for a combat focused turn-based strategy game that's a bit more lightweight than other games in the genre.

												This is a very light-weight Turn-based strategy game that is perfect for those new to the turn-based strategy genre of games. It has decent graphics for what it is and is customizable enough to provide hours or even days of play on a given map. I love the units' speech.If there were a downside to this game, I would suggest that you might start seeking some additional complexity after a while. Posted: April 8, 2016
												A well-crafted, easy-to-play game with an entertaining fantasy bent, Warlock will have you staying up nights taking one more turn to blast King Rrat to kingdom come. Think of it as Civilization V but with a fantasy setting. My biggest gripe with the game, that you can't refuse a demand. It's only accept or war. Which is annoying. However, it's everything one may want from a serious turn based strategy. It looks and feels like civilization, but has the intensity of Command and Conquer with the in-depth unit levelling system of Majesty. No steam workshop support but you can't have it all. It's a fun game that you will be saying to yourself, just one more turn.

Posted: March 14, 2014
												As far as strategy games go, it doesn't get much better than this.  Cities don't require a ton of micromanagement, while each choice is still important.  Every unit has it's advantages and limitations, and can level up in order to gain small bonuses or even entirely new abilities.  Vampires, for example, if leveled high enough, grant an aura effect to allies units that allows them a vampiric effect - 40% of the damage they deal, they get back as healing.  Terrain modifiers can easily make or break a battle, and powerful spells can alter that terrain.  The high level of freedom can also allow for many outside-the-box strategies, as well.  In one game, I used the "raise land" spell to create a small island, and then used the teleport spell to slowly ferry my troops across the ocean.  This allowed me to skip waiting on my navy to clear the ocean of sea monsters, and probably sped my conquest of a mostly empty continent by around 20 turns.The whole atmosphere of the game is light hearted, with a good deal of humor hidden within the description of the various units.  Even the units themselves can be good for a laugh, with anything from goblin archers saying reversing whether to aim or shoot first, to the fact that one of the strongest units in the game is a giant, fire-breathing turtle.  The game is still medieval fantasy, but it definately has a bit of fun with it.One common mistake I see, however, is the belief that this game is a clone of Civilization V.  In fact, this game isn't based on Civ V, it's based on another, much older game.  It does contain many modern updates of the old turn based strategy game design, such as hex grids and 3D graphics, as well as some entirely new material, like the terrain altering spells.  Still, it's long been the nature of every game to be compared to a single, super-popular game within it's own genre.  Kinda like how World of Warcraft is mentioned in virtually every conversation of whether some MMORPG is a good game or not.Overall, the gameplay is fantastic, the potential for strategic thinking is very high, and aside from an AI that makes me want to punch the other leaders in the face (mostly due to their manipulative design), I really do enjoy this game.  Heck, I've even found some ways to turn the AI's back-stabbyness against them.  Now if only the sequel would hurry up and get here.  =)P.S. Try the demo.  If you like it, consider Ultimate Edition, because there isn't a single expansion or DLC I didn't like for this game.

Posted: October 9, 2016
												This is definitely a warfare-focused 4X - diplomacy and trade are minimal, and most systems ultimately feed into warfare one way or the other. If you're looking for a more comprehensive fantasy 4X, try Endless Legend, but if war's what you're looking for, it's well worth it to give Warlock a go.Pros:- Tons of unity variety, a lot of it tied to local resources rather than faction- Interesting map generation- Good sense of tension even in the late game- Can summon volcanosCons:- Constant monster spawning via events is annoying- It can be hard to identify monster lairs on the map, as the art style is noisy and cluttered- The diplomatic AI seems fairly dumb, at least at lower levels, allowing me to make peace whenever it's convenient for me so I can heal my forces and hunt the monster spawners before declaring war again- Cannot summon volcanos directly underneath cities

Posted: December 17, 2014
												I had high hopes for this game. I thought it might be somewhat similar to XCOM, which was my first foray into turn-based strategy games. No such luck. Warlock - Master of the Arcane has no story, clunky controls, annoying voice-overs, cliche lore, and is painfully sexist. There is apparently no real campaign, just quests that randomly appear. The controls work some of the time, and there is no menu to map controls to different keys. The voice acting is stilted at best, and tends to be jarring. Play is slow and uninteresting. Out of all the character options (~12) there are two females - a healer and a dragon queen. There's no female undead character, or a female battle-mage, which was extremely disappointing. The only redeeming qualities? Well, the graphics are nice enough, but the best thing is I got this for free in a humble bundle, so I can throw this abysmal excuse for a strategy game away with no regrets. 2/10

Posted: November 30, 2015
												Given the price this is often at these days, this game is a great buy for anyone who ever played and loved Master of Magic.  I adored that game and still consider it the ultimate 4x experience.  The inspirations are obvious and many features and concepts are carried over here, including:Square/hex based fantasy 4x TBSMultiple dimensions (Warlock has more than one)Heroes (which again are overpowering later with enough enchantments)Hero equipment (Artifacts, which can be crafted here also)City management with buildings, resources, and enchantments (though not self-contained like in MoM)Even unit orders like Sentry and the waypointing systemIt should also be noted that this game is in the lore of the Majesty series of games, and you'll recognize much of the irreverent humor and religious pantheon.  The graphics and sound design are gorgeous as well, and I've not once had the game crash on me yet, even while on a 12-hour bender, saving and loading games multiple times.I think I still would prefer a modern remake of Master of Magic with multiplayer, but I definitely recommend Warlock.

Posted: December 7, 2015
												Failure diplomacy: You can't reject proposed deals of AI opponents, this automatically means war. This is annoying! Sure, I see no problem in AI opponents attacking me, if I too often reject them, but the automatism is tedious. (In Civilisation I like the fact hat all AI ​​opponents have a "mood", which can be influenced by the actions of diplomacy.)Failure control: Units can not wait permanently / are put to sleep. At the next round you have to give new commands to each and every one. Once you have more than 5 units, it's annoying!Failure options: You can hardly adjust something in the options for gameplay. For example: You must always watch combat animations and your units running around. If you do not want this, you have to click for every damn unit. For experienced players this should be adjustable.Failure steam: On the steam-start-screen you can choose whether you want to play right now or only read the manual. If you choose the manual, you get the message that this was not possible, because of some kind of “application error” and that you should contact the steam support.If you are looking on the internet, you will find no guidance. The steam support refers to the manufacturers and your are send to a forum (where you can ask questions if you log in with an account). All unsatisfactory and very awkward.A link will help:http://warlockmota.wikia.com/wiki/Warlock:_Master_of_the_Arcane_WikiAnd opening a PDF file: http://cdn.akamai.steamstatic.com/steam/apps/203630/manuals/PDX9405EU_Warlock_Onlinemanual.pdf?t=1385627678Otherwise the game is graphically superb. (And would make a total of more fun when the controll-settings and especially the KI would be better.)Manko Diplomatie: Vorgeschlagene Deals von KI-Gegnern kann man zwar ablehnen, dies bedeutet aber AUTOMATISCH Krieg. Das ist nervig! Klar kann einen der KI-Gegner angreifen, wenn man ihn zu oft zurückweißt, aber der Automatismus ist langweilig. (An Civ gefällt mir, dass die KI-Gegner eine "Stimmung" gegenüber anderen Spielern haben, die über die Aktionen in der Diplomatie beeinflusst werden können.)Manko Steuerung: Einheiten können nicht dauerhaft warten/schlafen gelegt werden, spätestens zu nächsten Runde muss man ihnen wieder neue Befehle geben. Sobald man mehr als 5 Einheiten hat, nervt's!Manko Optionen: Man kann über die Optionen kaum etwas für das Gameplay einstellen. Mann muss sich immer die Kampfanimationen ansehen und seinen einheiten beim Rumlaufen zusehen. Wenn man das nicht will, muss man bei jeder verdammten Einheit klicken. Das zieht für erfahrene Spieler Runden unnötig in die Länge und sollte einstellbar sein.Manko Steam: Im Startbildschirm von Steam kann, man wählen, ob man direkt spielen oder erst die Anleitung lesen möchte. Wählt man die Anleitung, so kommt die Meldung, dass dies nicht möglich sei, weil eine Anwendung fehle. Man solle den Steamsupport kontaktieren.Wenn man im Netz sucht, findet man keine Anleitung. Der Steam-Support verweist einen einfach an die Hersteller und die schicken einen in ein Forum, wo man dann Fragen stellen kann, wenn man sich dort mit einem Account einloggt. Alles unbefriedigend und sehr umständlich.Ein Link hilft: http://warlockmota.wikia.com/wiki/Warlock:_Master_of_the_Arcane_WikiUnd das sich öffnende PDF-File: http://cdn.akamai.steamstatic.com/steam/apps/203630/manuals/PDX9405EU_Warlock_Onlinemanual.pdf?t=1385627678Ansonsten ist das Spiel grafisch gelungen. Und würde insgesamt mehr Bock machen, wenn die Steuerung und vor allem die KI besser wären.

Posted: April 20, 2016
												This game is really enjoyable, as a fan of the hotm and total war series I have to say this is as close as I have seen to combining them. I bought Endless Legend first and I have to say this game makes that one look so incredibly dull in comparison. The only problem I have with warlock is the difficulty, even on the highest level, impossible, it is actually pretty easy. The ai does not know how to counter spells that affect pathing, so as cool as raising a mountain range to block enemies or beaching enemy ships is the ai does not have an effective way to counter the tactic. The raise/lower land spells come early too so there is really no way to lose if you know how to use them effectively. 90% of this game is fun but the 10% that includes chasing weak enemies that flank you to attack cities or getting to a point where winning is inevitible and spending 5 hours cleaing up is not fun.Conclusion: Buy this game if it is 15 dollars or less, you will enjoy it enough to make the purchase worth it at this cost or lower.

												Got this game for free. First time I played it, 2 years ago I played all evening and night and completed the game. That's right, I played for 14 hours straight, the first time I played this game, and I have never played something like this before (not Civ5 etc.). At this point I knew it's dangerously addictive, I just want to make my units stronger, my kingdom bigger, defeat all other mages, see what creatures I can get. Everytime I tell myself: "Just one more turn, then I'm call it a quit".now 3 days ago I started a new game. And see here; 20 hours later I completed it. Done in 3 days.This game is truly a good game, it is simple but you can immerse yourself into it as much as you like it. Posted: July 3, 2012
												It's a fixed Civ-like game where you control a fantasy race trying to take over a map.  Diplomacy is hilariously lackluster since you'll probably go to war after another civ demands all of your mana or gold, but that was never why I played these anyway.  Another thing is that you can cast various spells to affect the board such as summons, attacks, buffs, debuffs, and so on.  Units are also really important to keep alive since they gain feats when they level and keep all the feats when you upgrade them to the next type; you can also buy armor/weapons for them that stay, so they become a long-term investment most of the time.  It lets you skip through opponents' turns quickly so that's a HUGE plus for me, but at the end of the day you go through everything you can make in game pretty quickly, and these types of games usually don't hold my interest too long.7/10, awesome if it's on sale, but you'll probably find better value/fun elsewhere

Posted: September 28, 2016
												Great game, very similar to the Civilization series of 4X, with some coo, additions.I personally think that it lose comparing to civ, in my opinion it lack something of the mature and deep gameplay of other 4X games, but, indeed, fun to play and challenging at highest defficulty levels.Get it of you like 4X games or even if you are approaching the genre, because it's easy learning curve, you will find some hours of strategic fun

Posted: September 21, 2016
												An interesting fantasy 4X, that risks to be overlooked in favour of more recent or more famous titles.While it is no masterpiece, it certainly has its perks:- races- magic- different resources, not your usual- still easy on the eye- really challengingTo be honest, I must also recognise its cons:- factions of the same race are all the same, regardless of their different leaders- no technology, only spells to research- compared to a historical 4X (e.g. Civilization), it lacks depth and direction, but I feel that this is a pretty common problem with fantasy 4X- occasionally brutal, even at the lowest difficulties- some mechanisms are not intuitiveIt kind of feel like a con, but I couldn't put it together with all the others, since it is really not the game's fault: recently, the market has been invaded by fantasy 4X, and this one lacks such a personality to break the mould. If you like the genre, you should give it a try, because it still is a nice game, but if you already own Age of Wonders, Fallen Enchantress, Endless Legend, etc, you probably won't find anything to really set this game apart from the others.

Posted: October 9, 2016
												This is definitely a warfare-focused 4X - diplomacy and trade are minimal, and most systems ultimately feed into warfare one way or the other. If you're looking for a more comprehensive fantasy 4X, try Endless Legend, but if war's what you're looking for, it's well worth it to give Warlock a go.Pros:- Tons of unity variety, a lot of it tied to local resources rather than faction- Interesting map generation- Good sense of tension even in the late game- Can summon volcanosCons:- Constant monster spawning via events is annoying- It can be hard to identify monster lairs on the map, as the art style is noisy and cluttered- The diplomatic AI seems fairly dumb, at least at lower levels, allowing me to make peace whenever it's convenient for me so I can heal my forces and hunt the monster spawners before declaring war again- Cannot summon volcanos directly underneath cities

content:
Posted: April 20, 2016
												This game is really enjoyable, as a fan of the hotm and total war series I have to say this is as close as I have seen to combining them. I bought Endless Legend first and I have to say this game makes that one look so incredibly dull in comparison. The only problem I have with warlock is the difficulty, even on the highest level, impossible, it is actually pretty easy. The ai does not know how to counter spells that affect pathing, so as cool as raising a mountain range to block enemies or beaching enemy ships is the ai does not have an effective way to counter the tactic. The raise/lower land spells come early too so there is really no way to lose if you know how to use them effectively. 90% of this game is fun but the 10% that includes chasing weak enemies that flank you to attack cities or getting to a point where winning is inevitible and spending 5 hours cleaing up is not fun.Conclusion: Buy this game if it is 15 dollars or less, you will enjoy it enough to make the purchase worth it at this cost or lower.

												Got me hooked... again. Another late night, just one more turn, where did all my beer go? game. Like Civ, its a turn based 4X (whatever that means) strategy crawler that just won't cut it with the shooter crowd. But hey, nothing cuts it with the shooter crowd, they even complain about their favourites until they get nerfed to heck and go plan another shooter to moan about. THIS game has spells, and dragons, and plays like civilisations worst wet dream, just without the ridiculous evolving through the ages bollix. Go get it, play it, then tell your newly estranged partner that it wasn't your fault, Skull sent ya.

Posted: April 8, 2016
												A well-crafted, easy-to-play game with an entertaining fantasy bent, Warlock will have you staying up nights taking one more turn to blast King Rrat to kingdom come. Think of it as Civilization V but with a fantasy setting. My biggest gripe with the game, that you can't refuse a demand. It's only accept or war. Which is annoying. However, it's everything one may want from a serious turn based strategy. It looks and feels like civilization, but has the intensity of Command and Conquer with the in-depth unit levelling system of Majesty. No steam workshop support but you can't have it all. It's a fun game that you will be saying to yourself, just one more turn.

												This is a very light-weight Turn-based strategy game that is perfect for those new to the turn-based strategy genre of games. It has decent graphics for what it is and is customizable enough to provide hours or even days of play on a given map. I love the units' speech.If there were a downside to this game, I would suggest that you might start seeking some additional complexity after a while. I personally went on to the latest Civilization game and a few others. That doesn't detract from this game at all. Warlock is what it is and it is very good for the niche it fills.I heartily recommend it.
